business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —I declare that the following bills are urgent bills:

speech.para: That bills be considered urgent bills:
Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 and Customs and Excise Amendment (Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme) Bill 1999;
Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1999;
Taxation Laws Amendment (Demutualisation of Non-insurance Mutual Entities) Bill 1999;
Health Insurance Amendment (Professional Services Review) Bill 1999;
Criminal Code Amendment (Slavery and Sexual Servitude) Bill 1999;
Copyright Amendment (Computer Programs) Bill 1999;
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1999;
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1999;
Taxation Laws Amendment (CPI Indexation) Bill 1999;
Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999;
Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Amendment Bill 1999;
Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1999 and two related bills;
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999; and
Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1999-2000 and two related bills.
I move:

para.inline: That these bills be considered urgent bills.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

speech.para: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

I have moved this motion because here we have the government and, I presume, the Democrats moving a guillotine on a dozen pieces of important legislation so that it can be rammed through the Senate in the next 12 hours of debate. At the head of the list is the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 and an attendant bill which will have massive ramifications for this country and its environment. These Democrat-government bills deserve enormous scrutiny. They cannot get that scrutiny with the Democrats and the government using the guillotine. It involves a series of broken promises by the Democrats as they have sidled up to the government to sign away on the GST and at the same time provided through this mechanism a multi-billion-dollar gift to the mega-wealthy in this country, in particular to the mining industry and the big transport corporations. It does not pass my notice that these are prospective future donors to the Democrats, and it has not passed the notice of at least one Democrat senator that that is the case.

talk.start.para: —Really?

—Yes, really, Senator Lees. It is no wonder that Senator Lees interjects: she is the guillotiner on this occasion. More importantly, this is a total abrogation of the government's responsibility and the Democrats' committed policy to both the urban environment and the general environment of Australia, right from the tall forests of Tasmania through to downtown Sydney, Melbourne and every other city in Australia where there will be manifestly adverse results on public health through the emission of noxious pollutants and a great increase in the global warming problem through increased greenhouse gases. No doubt we will have a debate about that in the limited time available. If they stay in the chamber, I will be asking the Democrats a number of questions about their broken promises, in particular about the impact of this legislation on the environment of this country.

speech.para: This is a huge issue for politics in this country. It is an extraordinary sell-out of the interests of the Democrats, who once stood for equity. One minister—Senator Parer, I think—summed this up as a $2 billion plus advantage to the mining industry and one assessor has said that it is going to lead to profit increases for that sector of over seven per cent. That will not be through productivity increases or harder work. There may be other reasons for increasing or decreasing profitability. What is happening here is that the Democrats are handing billions of dollars per annum to these big corporations to sheet through as profit for their already wealthy shareholders. This is a gift that no other Australian will get. What the rest of Australia will get from the Democrats and the government is taxes on food and on a whole range of other necessary items. That is what this is about. That is why this guillotine is being used: to truncate debate. The Democrats should be ashamed of the devaluation of their own name through the use of this guillotine process to ram this legislation through the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be supporting the suspension motion that is before the chair. Obviously we have had a number of guillotine motions moved. At no stage has the opposition taken the approach of moving the use of a contingent notice of motion. I certainly accept that it is available for any senator to do so. Let me also make clear that, while we do not want to suspend standing orders and have an open-ended procedural debate, which would take valuable time from the matters of substance before the chair, we certainly will not be supporting the allotment of time motion. And consistent with the position we took earlier in the last sitting fortnight, we will not be supporting the guillotine.

speech.para: I think it is worth while to remind the Senate about what has occurred procedurally over the last few sitting days. We had a particularly deceitful guillotine motion agreed between the government and the Australian Democrats on the Telstra bill.

talk.start.para: —We did not agree anything. That is absolute nonsense.

—I apologise. It was not voted for by the Australian Democrats but, as I have made quite clear before, they were able to use their numbers in the Senate to ensure that guillotine was not put in place. You had a lot of clout, Senator Lees, as I have indicated before, particularly over the GST bill, but of course you decided not to use it. You did not use the political influence that you had on that particular occasion. We had a situation, and I think it was deceitful and treacherous, where the government negotiated an arrangement with the opposition in relation to extra sitting hours. Then the guillotine motion came in and Senator Lees and the Australian Democrats tried to use the cover of not voting for the guillotine motion but, at the same time, not using their political influence to ensure that guillotine did not go through. This is prior to the vote on the GST bill.

speech.para: Then you had of course the guillotine on the environment bill and that was an absolute outrage and disgrace, with 900 amendments before the chair and literally just a couple of hours to debate it. That is something where the Democrats lined up lock, stock and barrel with the government. It was probably one of the greatest procedural outrages that we have ever seen in the Senate and a complete sell out of the sort of position that the Democrats had previously taken in relation to these sorts of debates. The Democrats joined with the government and ensured that there was virtually no debate at all on the environment legislation, with a huge number of amendments before the chair—900 in all, with more than 500 sponsored by the government. That was an outrage and a disgrace that Senator Lees perpetrated on all those who have an interest in those issues. I believe that not only was proper process in this chamber sold down the river but so were the conservation groups, industry, the states and others who had an interest.

Of course, we had a guillotine for the tax bills. In my view, that was a more reasonable proposition because clearly there had been a lot of debate around that issue. I accept that there was an effort to try to ensure that there was a reasonable amount of time for debate. Some parts of the package of bills obviously deserved more debate than they got, and some less, but an attempt was made to ensure that we had a more fulsome debate than we saw on the environment bill. So it has been a very patchy record indeed in relation to the guillotine motion and I am sorry to say that the Australian Democrats have sold out in relation to these matters over the past few days.

The opposition will not support the urgency motion, consistent with the position that we have taken. We will also not be supporting the guillotine motion because we believe that the appropriation bills, in particular—although we accept that there are time constraints—are worthy of very considerable examination by this chamber.

talk.start.para: —Again, I think the comments from both the opposition and Senator Brown must be responded to, as we look at putting in place the measures by which we will ensure that we deal with the legislation that is urgent before us. If I could firstly respond to Senator Faulkner. We have never at any stage supported a further sale of Telstra. We did not support the guillotine or any of the processes in this chamber to speed up that passage.
—You did not stand up to it either.

—It is not up to us, Senator, to dictate to government what their program should be. Yes we can, whenever possible, use our influence on government, but in this particular case, as the government had the support from elsewhere, they were not even interested in talking to us, to be perfectly frank, so unfortunately we have seen a further sell off. That is nothing whatsoever to do with the Democrats and we remain opposed and will continue to be opposed.

speech.para: As we get into this debate on diesel and particularly looking at the bills that are before us, I again find Senator Brown's comments quite extraordinary and, as usual, very negative. The bill on diesel that we are about to deal with does not have any adverse impact on the environment. We will be debating this later on and I do not think it is my place in this debate now to go to the fine details of one of the bills that will be before us. But I do have to answer a couple of the comments from Senator Brown.

This is not, in his words, `a multi-billion dollar gift to some industry lobby group'; this is reducing the actual amount of subsidy to fossil fuels. If you look at the government's claims, I think, as Senator Allison will explain later, they have in fact got their own figures wrong and the modelling that was released recently shows that. What we have actually turned that around to is an additional impost of over $290 million on fossil fuels. I ask Senator Brown to start looking at the facts for a change and not to continue to rely on modelling by someone who has not bothered to look at all the details. As we get on, I think senators will see why it is important that we get this bill in place for rural and regional Australia. Actually reducing emissions and getting standards to the point where Australia will have some improvements on where we are now—not just improvements on the government bill—is extremely important.

Reducing emissions of greenhouse gases and particulate emissions is what this legislation is about and we should be dealing with it today. We cannot just keep putting it off until some senators find it more comfortable to bury it somewhere in the government's program. It is extremely important that we do look at this bill as part of the tax package because after all it was as part of that package that the government presented it to us. It is the government's agenda that we are dealing with. But we are actually very pleased with both the results we had on the environment bill and what we will see put in place today.

I say to senators, `Why the fuss?' We know that we are going to be putting in place a guillotine. I say to those senators who are keen to deal with the diesel bill, in particular—and I see that there is a very long list of people wanting to speak on the second reading and there is plenty of time for all those people to speak—we really should put this motion aside and get on with the business that is before us.

talk.start.para: —I am obviously going to speak to the procedural motion—that is, that we should suspend standing orders to allow the government to impose this guillotine with the agreement of the Democrats. Later on when we get to the substantive motion we will be talking about whether the bills are urgent, but this is just crazy. Senator Lees has just said, `We can't just keep putting it off and putting it off. Why all the fuss?' We are dealing with bills which have not even gone through the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. We are dealing with bills that do have specific problems. I will be dealing specifically with those problems later when we are talking about the substantive motion. We are also dealing with a bill that has a clause in it that says that it should not be imposed until the other emission standards have been legislated. The indications are that that will not be for at least 12 months.

speech.para: We are dealing with a bill that does not conform to the cut-off motion, we are dealing with bills which have not gone through the proper scrutiny process and we are dealing with bills that have not had the chance to be properly looked at in the committees, and yet we are being asked to suspend standing orders so a guillotine can be imposed because we cannot keep `putting it off and putting it off', according to Senator Lees.

This is madness. It is a total abuse of the democratic process within this place. To me it is abuse of the spirit of the standing orders and the processes by which not only we but also the community get to see these bills. Why should the Greens (WA) or any other party support the standing orders to suspend and to gag this debate? In effect that is what it is. It is a ridiculous process. It is a means of preventing scrutiny. It is not just a means of putting on a bill that is urgent. As I say, we will talk about the urgency in a bit more detail when we reach the substantive debate, but quite frankly it is ludicrous to suggest that this motion has to be put now and in this way.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief, Madam President. The first notable thing about the guillotines we have seen in the last week which is quite different from those in July of the previous year is that the guillotine resolutions them selves have not been gagged. I think that is a substantial advance in the attitude of the government because it does allow some debate. It also means that, on the two occasions we get in these debates to move a contingent notice of motion taking half an hour each, we have not once availed ourselves of that. Traditionally the argument so far has gone not so much to the urgency but to the time allotment.

speech.para: Let me deal with urgency first of all. I think it would be churlish to say that, given the rest of the tax package that has gone through, the diesel bills do not fit that category. Certainly, the appropriation bills are urgent. We would like them considered by 30 June. It is interesting that six weeks ago I was involved in a discussion where I said that the government would leave the appropriation bills right until the end and then come to us and say that they have to be pumped through. You did not have to be a genius to work out that that is exactly what they would do. As we had no debate on the budget—or the budget papers, effectively after the Thursday night—this is one of the greatest curtailments ever of the appropriation bills, and I think it should be recognised. The government, however, have recognised that and extended their original proposal by an hour. That in itself is helpful.

As for the urgency of most of these bills, the urgency is dictated by a previous guillotine. These are all listed for Thursday lunchtime, which does not indicate great urgency. A previous guillotine absorbed the Thursday lunchtime and now they all have to be put through. I have not been through them individually to find out where the substance in these may be that affects various individual senators around the chamber, but if they were listed and we agreed to them being listed for a Thursday lunchtime I do not think that we can argue they should not have been dealt with in this guillotine motion.

As we have said on a number of occasions in the last few weeks, we do not necessarily oppose the concept of a guillotine. What becomes critical is whether people can have their say at the time that it is imposed. That has been granted, at least. The second thing is to look at the hours. Senator Faulkner was right to do the review in which he basically conceded that an almost ample amount of time was allowed in the tax debate. When you look back on it we could have easily put a couple more hours into the first bill and taken a couple of hours off the later bills. You would have had to have been pretty much on top of all the legislation to have seen that, and I do not think anyone could have exercised that judgment at the time. In terms of the tax bills, we gave a commitment early in the piece to have the tax bills dealt with by 30 June and indicated that we would be opposing them. At least that has been met and that will be met with these diesel bills.

The tragedy for this chamber, frankly, was dealing with the environment bills. To have 400 new amendments come down at 4 o'clock one day and to vote the whole bill through by about 4 or 5 o'clock the next day was an absolute travesty of debate in this chamber. It just made this chamber a rubber stamp, which has been rare over the years, even in a guillotine situation. It made it virtually impossible for the shadow minister or anyone else to read, absorb and analyse those particular amendments. I hope it is not repeated in the future.

The other point has often been made in this chamber. You always look to track records on guillotines. We have never stood on our record on guillotines. Why should we? We have supported them in the past and, in supporting them in the past, we had to nominate all those in opposition that had previously supported them. It becomes a bit like PNG payback, doesn't it? At least we never moralised on the subject, unlike a party of seven others here who, when some of those guillotine motions came up, made a variety of enunciations about the rights of senators and democracy—all of which, at the first opportunity, went down the drain.

Finally, let me put this on the record: why did the Democrats agree to gag the environment bill? Because they did not want it out there for public discussion. The numbers are there to put it through in August, even more so than now. They did not want the pressure. They could not stand it any longer. They just thought, `Let's vote for the guillotine and end the pressure.'

We do not intend to support Senator Brown's resolution. It will be an open-ended debate; it will go on forever. All those comments should be made in a very brief debate around the motion for the actual allotment of time. We will not be supporting that particular motion but, on the other hand, we are not absolutely critical of every aspect of it. Some parts of it are acceptable. We would like as much time as possible on the appropriation bills.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that the motion to declare certain bills urgent, moved by Senator Campbell, be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the procedural motion, I indicated that I wished to speak a little bit more about the actual time allocation and the reasons for doing so. We have been given a list in relation to so-called non-controversial bills. We knew that it was a very large and, I always believed, unrealistic list. Over a period of time, a number of people have dropped everything at times to have a look at these bills. They have been talked to and talked at by various ministers in relation to the particular bills that the government said were going to be on the list for last Thursday. How urgent did the government think those bills were last Thursday? What time did they allocate to them? They actually took them off the program—and Senator Ray has alluded to that.

speech.para: The government chose to take those bills off the lunchtime program for Thursday. Not only that, it chose to take the lunchtime away. We have been left with the situation on a number of days since then, I believe unfairly, where the staff in this place were not able to get proper breaks or proper meals. I do not think that was taken into consideration when those original guillotines were put in.

We had a situation where, as Senator Faulkner has pointed out, not only were we pushed into an agreement about different times to allow extra debate on the bills that were on the program—which seemed totally unrealistic at the time—but also, the Senate having just come to that agreement, we then found that lunchtimes, dinnertimes and any break times went by the bye. That was for my staff, for the staff in this place and for the people who provide the services that we need. Let us face it, what must it be like for people, even those here in this chamber, who are supposed to be awake, rested, on their toes and keeping us supplied with the information that we need, if they are given no breaks during the day, or if they have to survive with minimal staff because some people are trying to fit a meal break in somewhere?

The issues of staff breaks and so on were not debated in the meetings of the leaders and whips. They just went like that—snap! Basically, we have a situation where the lunchtime bills which the government gave up last Thursday are now so urgent that they have to be put through. They were so-called non-controversial bills and now they are being rammed through as urgent. I believe most indications are that there might be some time constraints—and some were because the government wanted them—but there are still a heap of problems associated with bills like the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 which simply have not been properly scrutinised.

There is certainly a problem with whether or not there is any certainty at all with the commencement provisions. How can any government and how can the Democrats support the notion that a bill has to be rammed through right now at the end of a session without scrutiny when there is no certainty about the commencement provisions at all? These are certainly some of the weirdest commencement provisions that our office has seen as they depend on other things that are not certain themselves. We have a situation where the government cannot even tell us when the bills are due to commence. The government says, `Nevertheless, we have talked about them so much'—that is, we have not talked about them at all—`and we would just like to shove them through just in case you get a chance to look at them and scrutinise them in the meantime.'

There is some concern and some doubt over the constitutionality of this under section 92 of the Constitution. That issue has been raised since the in-principle so-called signing of the agreement. A range of anomalies are associated with the diesel bill, with arbitrary weights and definitions, and many of these have been raised by community groups and local governments. We believe that the extent of environmental destruction embodied in this bill, despite the protestations of Senator Lees, will cause greater environmental harm than we have now.

That has been clearly demonstrated by the statements of Dr Clive Hamilton, who has had to be very brave of late, I must say, to even speak up because, after previously having the confidence of the Australian Democrats, he is now being attacked for speaking out on the things that he believes are important. Groups such as Greenpeace, the ACF and others are also making strong statements about these bills. If the strategy of the Australian Democrats is to shoot the messenger, who is going to be left standing as credible advisers to the Australian Democrats on issues like pollution and the environment? Or will a decent amount of time pass and then somehow or other the Australian Democrats will try to make up with the groups that they have treated so badly during this process?

We believed that after the initial advice regarding the commencement provisions, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would do its job and raise serious concerns with the minister and ask for a `please explain', but it will not even get a chance to report before we debate the bills. What kind of open process is that? We have a committee in the parliament whose job is to see the problems of bills—the structural and constitutional problems of bills—and it is not going to be given a chance to report to this parliament. So we might well be rushing ahead, dropping everything and shoving through diesel fuel bills without being able to see what the report is from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. What sense does that make?

I have mentioned that the commencement provisions make the diesel concessions dependent on appropriations to certain environmental programs. We believe that, although there is some general statement in this direction, there is nothing that requires the government to make those appropriations and to set standards to be reached. So it might be that this bill never takes effect. I will repeat that: we have a situation where, as far as we can read from this bill, this bill may never take effect.

We believe that this unusual commencement provision would have been picked up by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and I imagine it would have liked to have seen that the commencement provisions were certain rather than left in the air. The committee has the responsibility, as the elected holder of legislative power, to determine whether the laws we make come into force and how they come into force. We believe that the kind of commencement provision in the diesel fuel bills is in fact in conflict with the spirit of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel's drafting instruction No. 2 of 1989. That says that the commencement clause `should be repealed if the events that trigger the commencement' do not occur.

So we have a situation where there are no guarantees that those events will occur, we know that there have been changes after deals have been made and we know that there is nothing that we can see in the bill that would require them to actually occur, other than some line on a piece of paper that may or may not be adhered to. This is not good enough for the process within this parliament, it is not good enough for scrutiny and it is not good enough for the way that staff and other people in this parliament have been treated. I strongly oppose the allocation of time motion that the government has moved.

talk.start.para: —I support Senator Margetts completely. The Greens are going to totally oppose the first bill on this list, which has the massive, multi-billion-dollar hand-out to the big corporations through the diesel rebate system that the Democrats have now signed up to. I must draw to your attention that there are now enough government and Democrats speakers on that bill to ensure that we do not get a committee stage. Senator Lees gets up and says we will be able to debate this; we will not. The Democrats are going to cut out analysis of this bill. There are going to be second reading debate speeches and there will be precious little time left, if any—in fact, it appears there will be none. If each of the speakers on the second reading takes their time, we will get no time to look at amendments. We will get no time to analyse the way in which this legislation increases the gap between the haves and the have-nots in this country and the way in which it gives $3 billion a year to the big mining, logging and other corporations while ordinary people get the GST on their takeaway foods.

speech.para: Senator Lees interjected on me a bit earlier and asked who among the Democrats was looking at how there might well be some interest taken in what the Democrats are doing. Let me quote here:

Commenting on the Democrats' annoyance at the corporate donations imbalance, Senator Murray said, `They pour money into the major parties and give zip to us because they do not see us as significant.'

Now that the GST and the diesel fuel rebate, with its munificence to those big corporations, are afoot, we will no doubt have the Democrats thinking that they are in the big league. This allocation of time is totally inadequate, given a multi-billion-dollar matter like this, for the Senate to debate this matter and to represent the interests of people all over the country. Last week, as Senator Faulkner said, the Democrats guillotined the most backward piece of environmental legislation in half a century in this parliament. This week they are guillotining this piece of legislation with its massive impacts on the environment and with a huge hand-out, particularly to the mining corporations, without even enough time for a committee. That is the level to which the Democrats have descended.

talk.start.para: —As I indicated, the opposition will not be supporting this allotment of time motion. I think everyone understands in these debates that the more time you eat up on the allotment of time debate, the less opportunity there is, in fact, to debate the substantive legislation before the chamber. Long speeches can be a little self-defeating in these sorts of debates when there is a proposal for a guillotine at 8.30 in the evening. I want to make absolutely clear that we have probably one of the more reasonable guillotine motions before the chamber at the moment when you compare it with what we have had over the past couple of weeks.

speech.para: It is worth remembering what the chamber has faced in recent days. On Monday last week, we had a situation where the further privatisation of Telstra legislation was before the chamber and, with the contrivance of the Democrats, a guillotine was imposed to ensure that particular bill was dealt with this session as quickly as possible before the numbers in the Senate changed on 1 July. That ensured a further sell down of Telstra. The responsibility for that is fairly and squarely in the court of the Australian Democrats because the Australian Democrats absolutely refused to use any political leverage on the government at all.

That guillotine motion, which technically but very transparently the Australian Democrats opposed, was passed before the GST package was dealt with. Everyone knows that the Australian Democrats had an awful lot of leverage over the Prime Minister. They did not appear to have the capacity to use it, but they had an enormous amount of political influence they were either unwilling or unable to use. That is what happened on Monday after the government, in a very deceitful and treacherous way, sought agreement from around the chamber on extension of sitting hours but did not bring other parties—no doubt, they brought the Democrats—into the picture.

Senator Bartlett is shaking his head. If they did not bring you into the picture, Senator Bartlett, you should have done something about it. But you did nothing—absolutely nothing. That is the problem. Either you are the world's worst political operator and you were duped and conned by the government, or you are in the fix. You cannot have it both ways. That is the problem. If you were not apprised of this, perhaps you can explain your actions to the Senate and to the Australian people, because you are wholly and solely responsible for a further sell down of Telstra.

talk.start.para: —You have made a very good point.

—Thank you, Senator Carr—you will get on! I want to move to another guillotine motion, in relation to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1999 . This time the Democrats voted with the government for the guillotine motion, which meant that we had a committee stage, under guillotine on 23 June 1999, of five hours and 11 minutes. This was perhaps the most important legislation in relation to environmental protection that we have seen in this parliament for many years, and it was perhaps the most important in relation to the watering down of the capacity of the Commonwealth government to protect Australia's environment. The environment package had more than 900 amendments—it had more than 500 government and Democrat sponsored amendments—and was dealt with in five hours and 11 minutes. There was no involvement of, or exposure to, those who have an interest in this issue from whatever side of the debate they come from.

speech.para: We know the Australian Democrats deliberately and clinically made a decision to count the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Wilderness Society and Greenpeace out of the debate. That was their decision; and when you make these decisions, you have to live with them. That was the decision that the Australian Democrats made. Not only were those groups counted out but so was everyone with an interest in the environment. It does not matter from what perspective—whether you are a member of a conservation group, whether you are just an interested Australian, whether you happen to be a state government or whether you happen to be from industry—the government and the Australian Democrats have achieved what I thought was the unachievable: they have got the backs up of not only the conservation constituency but indus try as well. That is the achievement. Secret deals have been done by the Democrats and the government, and no-one is let into the secret at all. There is no transparency, there is no capacity for scrutiny of the government by other senators if you do not happen to be a member of the Australian Democrats or the government. Forget about the rights of others to ensure there is proper legislative scrutiny—that is all forgotten and swept under the carpet. Many thousands of Australians and important interest groups have been clearly kept out of the debate and have not been allowed to express a view at all. They are not able to see the arrangements that the government and the Democrats have come to on such an important piece of legislation.

We had the same guillotine motion on the tax bills. That was in a sense more reasonable; I think most people would accept that. There had been a long committee debate, and the bills had received a lot of parliamentary examination and scrutiny. The guillotine motion, as it worked in relation to the GST package, was probably reasonable in some of its elements and turned out to be totally inadequate in others. We had a situation in relation to the GST package where a great deal more parliamentary scrutiny by the Senate would have been appropriate for some bills and some key aspects of the debate; others, it turned out, were adequate. At least we were not faced with a situation of the guillotine being dropped in having just put in the arrangements for extending sitting hours in the Senate, which, as I have said in relation to Telstra, was a particularly deceitful way of progressing.

Today we move to a new allotment of time resolution, a new guillotine. This is one that in some of its elements seems to be reasonable enough. I do accept the arguments that are put forward in relation to part (3) of the guillotine allotment of time motion, which applies to a range of bills that I think most parties and senators would agree could have been dealt with non-controversially. Because a previous guillotine motion had taken up the time for non-controversial legislation, some of this legislation, unless it came before the chamber in this form, would not be able to be dealt with.

Time will tell whether the amount of time provided in this allotment of time resolution is adequate or not. It is hard to make a judgment now, but I think any reasonable person would accept that at least it had been previously promoted that this package of bills was non-controversial legislation. I am concerned about taking too much time on the allotment of time motion because it means that we will have less time for the substantive debate on the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 , and that is important legislation.

The opposition has many points it wants to make in that substantive debate, particularly about ensuring we have maximum opportunity to deal with the appropriation bills. I acknowledge that the government has increased the amount of time that was originally provided in the first draft allotment of time motion. I suppose it goes to show—and perhaps the Manager of Government Business in the Senate will acknowledge—that the more consultative the government is on these things the better these sorts of processes work. We have indicated that, while we oppose the allotment of time motion, we do want to get on with the substantive debate before the chamber. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I need to respond to a few of the comments made by other people in speaking to this motion which sets out a time frame for a number of pieces of legislation. Firstly, I want to respond to some of the comments to do with previous decisions of the Senate in relation to other allotment of time motions and resolutions in the last week or so.

speech.para: We have the continued misrepresentation that somehow or other the Democrats are responsible for enabling the Telstra legislation to come on to a vote. I do not know what more a party can do than vote against something coming on for a vote. Despite the fact that the Democrats are moving into a stronger position in this chamber in a couple of days time, as it stands now, if the government can get the agreement of two Independents, it can get anything it wants through this chamber regardless of our position. That is obviously what happened in relation to the Telstra legislation. To suggest that somehow or other the Democrats are responsible for that is clearly a bit of an absurd misrepresentation. The Democrats outlined our position on that allotment of time motion and the broader legislation at the time, and there is not really much point in revisiting that debate now.

On the environment legislation, as I said at the time, personally I would have been very keen to spend more time highlighting the significant achievements and benefits that the Democrats have gained and to highlight the fact that the Democrats have now managed to ensure that there is an increased amount of power for the federal government over the environment and a range of issues that the federal government and the federal environment minister can now act on in environmental issues. That is a point that obviously has not got through to a lot of environment organisations. If there had been more time to better highlight that, it would have been nice. But, as was indicated by Senator Faulkner in his comments, a number of groups, including industry, are quite upset about what the Democrats achieved in that area, which perhaps gives some indication why it was important to ensure that the legislation was passed whilst the opportunity was there.

It also gives the lie to the fairly fatuous cheap shots from Senator Brown that somehow or other the Democrats are selling out our principles because we are seeking to get more financial support and be more focused in getting donations from throughout the Australian community. I certainly do not hide the fact. He quoted Senator Murray, and I am quite happy to back up Senator Murray's comments. The Democrats get far fewer donations than the larger parties, and I am very keen to reverse that particular situation. All people in the Australian community know what the Democrats' policies and principles are. They know that we will stand up for those principles and that we will act in accordance with those. We are quite up-front about what we hope to achieve. We would seek support—financial or otherwise—from any source that is willing to help us to imple ment our policies and objectives. That is, as I understood it, what political parties are meant to be about, and it is certainly what the Democrats aim to do.

We are about demonstrating not only that we will be true and consistent to our policies and our principles but also that we have the power—an increased amount of power—in the new Senate to seek to implement those policies and principles and we have the willingness to use that power. I am certainly not going to hide that. I certainly will not stand in the way of getting extra support from any organisation that wants to assist us in providing funds for us to exercise our power to implement Democrat policies; it sounds good to me. I do not see why Senator Brown seems to think that this is some big conspiracy. I am quite happy to be up-front about that, in case anyone seems to think that it is something we need to hide.

In terms of the allocation of time available for debate, we have four hours plus time before question time today to look at the diesel legislation. I think the more time that we have on that legislation the better to highlight again the falsehoods and misinformation that continue to be spread and that Senator Brown has continued to highlight. The more opportunity we can get to put to rest and to try to counter some of that misinformation obviously the better from the point of view of the Democrats. But of course we do actually need to get the legislation passed, along with these other pieces of legislation, so we have had to balance that out in coming to an allocation of time.

We will certainly be using that time to highlight the facts on this issue. My colleagues will be outlining the fact, as the modelling released yesterday indicates, that the revised package will result in a reduction of greenhouse gas particulate emissions below what they would otherwise have been, and that the Australian Greenhouse Office's estimate on greenhouse suggests that the original ANTS package would have increased emissions by nearly two million tonnes but that the Democrats' changes reduce this by 5½ million tonnes to a net reduction overall of 3.6 million tonnes, using the most conser vative methodology available. The independent referee for that report, Dr David James, says that the 5.5 million figure is likely to be a significant underestimate of the gains. The Democrats will certainly be keen to put facts like those on the record through the debate on the diesel legislation.

The other 17 bills that are to be considered—which Senator Brown called important and crucial legislation, and I am sure he will be able to tell us what they are all about as I am sure he has fully studied them—are all matters that were considered to be non-controversial by all parties last week. Presumably, all parties would not have agreed to them being non-controversial unless they knew what was in them and believed that it was not inappropriate to enable them to be passed in a lunchtime session. These are all bills for which there was indicated unanimous support, or that no-one in the chamber is wanting to oppose. So they are ones that the Senate is able to deal with in a responsible fashion, and ensure that, in its role as a legislative body, as much legislation as possible is able to be got through.

About three hours is available for the debate on the appropriation bills, and I think that will prove to be adequate to consider that legislation, which obviously needs to be passed before the Senate rises at the end of 30 June. It is—as I acknowledge opposition speakers have conceded—a fairly reasonable allocation of time for these various bills, based on a reasonable assessment of the amount of time that is likely to be available.

Probably one of the other most important aspects of this allotment of time from the Democrats' point of view is not just that the legislation is there and the ability to provide adequate scrutiny of the legislation in accordance with its degree of controversy or importance but also what is not listed there. As part of ensuring that these bills are dealt with, the Democrats have been able to guarantee, through our willingness to exercise our power where we have had the opportunity and the numbers to do so, that the Regional Forests Agreement legislation is not going to be considered this session. It will be considered next session, and that is something the Democrats have delivered on.
Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Despite all the rhetoric from Senator Brown and others that, somehow or other, the Democrats have sold out on forests and that agreeing to the environment bill guillotine meant that the forests bill would come on—once again, they have been proven wrong. The Democrats have delivered by ensuring that the RFA bill will not come up until the next session.
—You need more time to surrender.

—Which means, of course, that the ALP, whose new-found concern for the environment was demonstrated so admirably last week—and we are very pleased to see the ALP concerned about the environment now—will have two months to look at that legislation and will have two months to be aware of the impact that it will have on Australia's native forests. To all the conservation organisations around the country who have expressed concern about the RFA bill and the need to put it off until the next session, we can certainly say that the Democrats have delivered on that. I certainly say to them and to the broader community, who do have such concerns for our native forests: make sure that you hold Labor honest to their new-found concerns for the environment and ensure that, when Labor do come back here in two months time, when that bill comes on, they act in accordance with their rhetoric over the last week and join with the Democrats in trying to prevent—
—You passed it last week. Don't back out on it now.

—Senator Brown says that we passed it last week. We are talking about a bill that will be dealt with next session; he is still trying to pretend that we have somehow or other enabled it to pass. The Democrats have ensured that it will not be able to pass without the support of the ALP, and I look forward to the ALP joining the Democrats in the next session in stopping this threat to our native forests. Similarly, the Democrats have ensured that the VSU legisla tion will not come on for debate in this chamber. So those student unions are now in a position where they know that that legislation will not pass unless we get a backdown from the ALP on that one, which I think we would be reasonably confident will not happen—
—Oh, come on! You're the sometime experts.

—I acknowledge the horror from Senator Carr as an indication that that is not going to happen. I think that is something that the Democrats and student unions around the country will be pleased about—that the Democrats achievement here in ensuring that the VSU bill does not come on will now guarantee that that legislation will not pass, and I welcome the Labor Party's expression of support for the Democrats' position in that regard. (Time expired)

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME BILL 1999

cognateinfo.title: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE AMENDMENT (DIESEL FUEL REBATE SCHEME) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I present the Bureau of Transport Economics report entitled Analysis of the impact of the proposed taxation changes on transport fuel use and the alternative fuel market .

—This is the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 . It is a bill that fits into the package of GST bills because it deals with diesel fuel subsidies. It is a bill that was rushed quickly through the House of Representatives last week as a matter of urgency, with insufficient opportunity to debate and analyse the content of the bill in the lower house. Proof of that assertion is found by the fact that, today, the government is proposing to amend it.

speech.para: Last week it was urgent and pure and could not be changed; this week they have found a fault and want to make an amendment. That is just one piece of evidence among many that this is hastily thought out legislation over a hotchpotch, patched up compromise between the government and the Australian Democrats. I want to mark the spot with this piece of legislation, as I did with some others yesterday—there will be errors in the implementation of it, unforeseen consequences that will come back to this chamber. Legislation is being sprung on us here without proper consideration and, when it is implemented, it will be the Australian community that suffers and the remedy will have to be found back here legislatively. But the fault for that suffering, and this is the spot I want to mark, will belong entirely to the government and the Australian Democrats because of their refusal to allow proper scrutiny—witness the guillotine motion that has just now been carried.

This bill represents a trade-off between two mutually antagonistic positions. It also represents a betrayal of the government's own electoral mandate, which they continue to assert ought to be superimposed on the Senate, but that is another story and it is one for them to explain to their own supporters. Why did they sell out on what they promised to do? That is a question for the Liberal Party.

The two mutually antagonistic positions that this bill tries to deal with are the claims by the government, with the support of its coalition partner, the National Party, that the best deal they can give to the bush and the regions is by reducing the cost of diesel fuel for both on-farm and vehicle use in the country. One of the big selling points about why a GST is good for the bush revolved entirely around the reduction in diesel fuel costs for farmers. That was the selling point. In fact, the Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, and his deputy, Mr Anderson, both promised to resign if they did not deliver in full the $3½ billion worth of savings that the government calculated would be the cost savings in fuel expenses to people in rural Australia. They have not delivered that; I see no resignations coming through. They most emphatically have not delivered that. In terms of the GST package, that was what the government proposed.

Of course, that brought an uproar from, among others, the Australian Democrats because this meant that, by reducing the cost of diesel fuel, you would encourage greater use of diesel fuel and, because this is a heavily polluting fuel, you would encourage greater pollution. That is supported by a lot of other evidence that we received before the Senate inquiry into the GST legislation—that is, that respiratory problems as well as greenhouse problems for Australia were being affected.

The Democrats would have you believe that, while this still encourages the greater use of fuel—diesel fuel in particular—even with all those problems they complained about, the fact that they have added in some subsidies for alternative fuels somehow makes it right. The Democrats will say that this is a fair compromise because the main areas of pollution are cities and they are keeping the subsidies out of the cities. By putting those two mutually antagonistic propositions together—using more fuel at cheaper prices, and using less fuel and causing less pollution by trying to quarantine where that fuel is used—they have got the worst of both worlds. They have got not a win-win situation but a total lose-lose situation for both points of view.

This is a silly bill, it is a patchwork bill, and it is a bill that sells out both the National Party and the Democrats—and I do not need to go very far to find evidence about that. What does the President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Mr Peter Garrett—a distinguished and well-known Australian whom the Democrats have been hitherto fond of quoting in this chamber—think about this compromise? Bearing in mind he is speaking not for his pop group Midnight Oil but as President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, he described this bill as a `dirty deal done dirt cheap'. Those are the words of Peter Garrett. As a consequence, he got one in his ear from Senator Lees on the basis that somehow or other the ACF, one of the foun dation organisations of the environment movement in Australia, is not trustworthy, cannot be confided in and leaks. Here we have an example of criticism from an environmental watchdog that has no axe to grind as far as this tax package is concerned; it is only arguing for the protection of the environment and about the compromise on the GST, and for their pains they get attacked by the Australian Democrats because the criticism is unwelcome.

And what do we get from the National Party? There have been murmurs throughout the bush that the National Party, by compromising as they have on this legislation, have sold out the real interests of rural Australia. That anxiety is expressed by the unusually large number of National Party senators who are going to speak in this debate in order to protect their rears and to try to persuade rural Australians that they have done the right thing when, as this is a compromise, they have watered down their position and it is not a win-win position; they have lost out for parts of the bush.

When the Australian Democrats, leading into the last election, put to the people what their position would be on this issue, they attached the memorable phrase that this was `not negotiable'. And what have we seen as a consequence? They negotiated on it. And did they keep to the levels that they had promised? No, they did not. They sold them down, and they said they had to do this to get an outcome. The Australian Democrats were in the prime position of bargaining, if ever any political party has been in such a prime position. This is, front and centre, an environmental matter—something that the Democrats have built their reputation on standing up for. When the Prime Minister said he would not agree, they only had to say in response, `Then we won't pass the GST,' and the Prime Minister would have had nowhere to go. The fact that they backed down and blinked when they saw the whites of his eyes shows that they are not only not good negotiators but they are prepared to compromise their electoral mandate when it suits political opportunity and in order to achieve a transitory period in the glare of television cameras, somehow resolving the issue of the GST.

What this debate this week and last has shown is that there is now an indelible entry on the record of Australian political history: we are going to get a GST, and we are going to get a GST by courtesy of the Australian Democrats. That is an albatross they will wear around their necks because the voters will not forget them. And we are going to get a GST by courtesy of this compromise, which, as I said, sells out the interests of both the National Party and the Australian Democrats.

Let me go to some substantive matters. One of the reasons we were concerned about the level of pollution in metropolitan Australia and elsewhere created by an excessive use of diesel fuels was because of evidence given before the Senate committee into the GST by, among others, the Australian Medical Association. This organisation is not in any way a frivolous body. It is an organisation with which, from time to time, I have had disagreement, but it is a substantial body which speaks on behalf of doctors in Australia. The President of the AMA gave evidence about the high levels of pollution already in our capital cities—which will not be reduced by this legislation; in fact it will be increased. Dr David Brand said this to our inquiry:

Medical evidence is mounting on the dangers of fine particles in diesel exhausts. I am particularly concerned by the evidence that these fine particles may lead to the premature deaths of 1,000 Australians every year. My medical colleagues have linked these particles to increased risk of lung cancer and a variety of respiratory disorders. The Government should take heed of these medical indicators and take steps to reduce, not increase the use of diesel in our cities.

talk.start.para: —Do you want to ban leaded fuel?

—No. I am saying that—just as you, Senator Lightfoot, would have defended the cigarette industry when the early medical evidence was that cigarettes cause lung cancer—we have here the president of an eminent medical body saying that excessive burning of these fuels in built-up areas of Australia causes the deaths of 1,000 Australians a year. People might want to say that is not true, but they had better deal with it on the scientific facts, because that is where the AMA is coming from. And it is these interests that have been sold out by this legislation.

speech.para: The other thing in this legislation that ought to be pointed to before I go to some of its more complicating elements is that there is a reference here to emission standards. The sensible course would have been to agree on emissions standards, and the Australian Labor Party would have been prepared to be party to a deal that encoded proper emission standards rather than to not go to emission standards but look at targets. The targets that are being looked at are, of course, European ones.

Anyone in the automobile industry knows that the benchmark targets for fuel emissions in the world are in California and that the Californian fuel emission standards are the highest around. If you want to sell a car in the United States, you had better build one that conforms with the Californian standards. I believe we are undershooting the best level of standards and that we could have gone to a higher level of test here, which would have not only helped our manufacturing export industry but also helped the environment in this nation. So let us deal with that matter as well.

Finally, there are a number of complications in this legislation that are best brought out by going to the explanatory memorandum. In the explanatory memorandum, which explains the meaning of this bill, they try to grapple with the patched-up compromise that has been reached here. I will quote from the explanatory memorandum. See if you can understand this:
The grant—
which is a fund that the government will now pay out to users of these fuels—
will be available for all on road use of these fuels in vehicles with a gross vehicle mass of 20 tonnes or more.

The grant will be available for on road use of these fuels in vehicles with a gross vehicle mass of 4.5 tonnes to 20 tonnes used for transporting goods or passengers. However, for vehicles under 20 tonnes, the grant is not available for sole use of the relevant fuels in the following metropolitan areas:
. Newcastle-Sydney-Wollongong;
. Melbourne-Geelong;
. Sunshine Coast-Brisbane-Gold Coast;
. Perth;
. Adelaide; and
. Canberra.

So you get it if you are using these fuels in a vehicle with a gross vehicle mass of 20 tonnes or more. Depending on where you use the vehicle, you will get it in a vehicle of from 4.5 tonnes to 20 tonnes but you will not get it in the metropolitan area for under 20 tonnes, and you will be self-regulating.

Just pause for a minute and think about the practical administrative steps necessary to enforce that piece of legislation. If you drive a vehicle out of the metropolitan area, as soon as you cross the border of the metropolitan area into country Australia you are suddenly eligible, if your vehicle is of 4.5 tonnes or more, for this benefit. If you drive back into the metropolitan area, you are suddenly not eligible.

You have to regulate the bookkeeping yourself and tell the truth to the tax office—as we know everyone does. So why wouldn't you claim that a substantial part of your journey was outside the metropolitan area, in order to attract the benefits of this legislation? Who could prove that it was not, if you made that assertion? It is self-regulating. When you think about that, why wouldn't you claim some sort of benefit, whether you were using your vehicle in or outside the metropolitan area? After all, how do you define easily the limits of the metropolitan area, given the urban sprawl that is dominating the eastern coast of Australia and parts of Western Australia as well?

This is an administrative nightmare and an open invitation to tax evasion. This is an open invitation to pass a cheque book to owner-drivers who want to exploit the system. Because it is self-regulatory, we will have to take their word for it. Who ever asked the Australian taxpayer, `You pay your taxes, and we will give them away in this way'? This is the most porous, easily exploitable system of handing out money that there has ever been. This is a confection of the government and the Australian Democrats.

Accountability in public expenditure is an important issue for governments in this country. But what do we have? A lack of accountability enshrined in legislation that we are guillotining through today with an inability to actually go through it properly in the considered detail that is necessary to point out the further issues that are a problem here. They are some of the reasons.

Under this legislation, if you are driving a truck from Melbourne to Geelong, that is deemed to be the metropolitan area of Australia and so you do not get the benefit of this legislation. If you make a detour out of that corridor and go into rural Australia, then you do get some benefit from this legislation. If you are driving from almost any other point in country Australia, you get the benefit of the legislation but not as soon as you enter the metropolitan area, which is also deemed to be Newcastle-Sydney-Wollongong and the Sunshine Coast-Brisbane-Gold Coast—all of those things not being defined clearly, so that you actually know where you are—so you either get the benefit or you do not get the benefit. As I say, this is a dog's breakfast.
I want to move an amendment to the second reading of this legislation, which I will now turn to. The amendment that I propose to move begins:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:—

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, that is not the second reading amendment that I have.
—Sorry. It has been re-crafted. I wish to quote not the lead-in text but the actual words of the amendment I propose to move to the second reading of this legislation.
—Are we on sheet 1461?
—We are indeed. I move:

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for proposing arrangements which will:
(i) impose a compliance nightmare on Australian transport operators;
(ii) breach Australia's international greenhouse gas reduction obligations;
(iii) worsen air quality in Australian cities;
(iv) be wide open to abuse;
(v) increase the cost of using public transport;
(vi) retard the development of Australian solar industries and energy efficient technology; and

(b) recommends that the Government introduce clean diesel fuel programs, and tighter vehicle emission standards, such as those operating in the United States and the European Community to improve the air quality and hence living conditions of Australians living in urban areas".

I want to conclude my participation in this debate by going back to the original premise. There are two mutually antagonistic ideas: cheaper fuel, higher consumption, more pollution on the one side; lower consumption, more subsidies out of the public purse on the other. And there is a contention that in the first case we add to economic efficiency, which is undoubtedly true, but without considering the social dimension and other hidden economic costs of that efficiency, and in the second case that we are actually consuming less and protecting the environment and the health of Australians.

When we vote on this legislation, I think a great deal of weight should be placed on what the Australian Medical Association has said. Any Australian who considered the debate on cigarettes and lung cancer will recall that in the early days medical prophets who argued that cigarettes contribute to lung cancer and the early death of smokers were rubbished by vested interests and told that they were prophets of doom who had no scientific basis for what they said. What is being put to us now by the medical profession is that the same impact can be had on human health by excessive fuel emissions. Their words should be taken—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the outset of this debate, I declare an interest in the bill as a primary producer and user of distillate. Unfortunately, in the months ahead I will be burning a lot more distillate than I have been burning up until the present. I support the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 . I think it is a great step forward. Distillate is very import ant to rural Australia. Senator Cook would not realise it, but many properties carry no petrol on the premises at all. They hold only diesoline because all their equipment—tractors, trucks—use that as their fuel source. Also, Australia is the only country I can think of, off the top of my head, where distillate is either the same price as petrol or sold at a higher price. Most countries market dieseline at a lower price than petrol.

speech.para: I want to talk about one of the practical elements in relation to this bill. Firstly, I would like to address the basic principle that Senator Cook was labouring so heavily through his speech. His basic proposition was that cheaper fuel leads to more consumption and therefore more pollution.
Senator Brownhill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As Senator Brownhill interjected, that is a totally incorrect assumption. We are talking about the commercial use of fuel here. No-one sits on a tractor and drives it around a property to look at the scenery. They do it because they are hauling a plough or digging a hole with a bucket—something like that. Similarly, they do not drive trucks around the place unless they have a load of cattle or feed on board, or produce which they are taking somewhere.

speech.para: Farming is a commercial business, not a pleasure business. So the consumption of fuel will not increase in any way at all. All that will happen is that the profitability of rural enterprises will become marginally better because one of their inputs will be a little bit cheaper. If that is the only criticism of any substance in Senator Cook's speech—it was hard to find anything else of any substance in it—then he really ought to be supporting the bill.

One of the other arguments he ran was the health argument, basing it on a claim by the AMA some weeks ago that we should oppose the bill because there would be a lot of dangerous carcinogens out in the air as a consequence of this increased consumption. Probably all hydrocarbon fuels contain carcinogens. I am not dogmatic on that point because I have not surveyed the whole range of hydrocarbon fuels. Certainly petrol contains carcinogens. It is probably also true that those carcinogens are in molecular form and are therefore invisible—they are not visible as smoke.

I welcome the fact that the bill looks at the emission control standards for diesel engines. One of my concerns is the state of the maintenance of so many diesel trucks in Australia. One of the characteristics of a very large number of Australian diesel trucks is their exhaust signature. In plain language, I am talking about the huge clouds of black exhaust smoke which come out, particularly when the truck is under load. This exhaust cloud consists of carbon particles and incompletely combusted fuel, and sometimes even raw fuel droplets. You can argue as to whether or not the visible sign of that exhaust signature is a carcinogen. Certainly, the particulate matter acts as a respiratory irritant and is a general degrading element in the community. The point must be made that a properly tuned and maintained diesel engine has no visible exhaust signature at all.

If you ask most people in the community how they pick a diesel from a petrol engine, their immediate reply would be, `We pick it by the black exhaust smoke that's coming out of it.' That is a consequence of a badly maintained engine. The black exhaust smoke comes from dirty fuel injectors and from worn engines, and some operators open up the fuel rack on the fuel pump so that they get more fuel into the engine to get greater power because often they overload trucks. It is a well known fact that many commercial vehicles are operating up to twice the designed all-up weight for their load.

Senator Cook talked about emission standards in California, which I think are very interesting. Next time honourable senators are in California, I invite them to go to Los Angeles, get out on the freeways and have a look at the trucks going along. You will not see any exhaust signature at all on a Californian vehicle. You will see heat waves shimmering out of the exhaust pipe when they pull up at the stop signs. You can see them carrying heavy loads at high speeds, going up inclines and hills and you will not see any trace at all of signature.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's promise made in parliament last Wednesday that `the states will keep arrangements providing for rebates on cellar door and mail order sales for wineries of up to $300,000.' Did the Treasurer go on to claim that he understood that `South Australia has already indicated that it will'? Is it not a fact that the South Australian Treasurer, Mr Lucas, stated in the South Australian parliament only an hour or so later that he was `not aware of any agreement that had been entered into by the states to maintain arrangements for the exemption'? Can the minister now confirm that the Treasurer was relying on a submission from the Winemakers Federation of Australia to the Senate when he made his misleading claims in parliament? Isn't this hopeless shambles just another example of the policy making on the run which has characterised the government's chronic adhockery in its negotiations with the Democrats? What guarantees has the federal government received from the states that the tax exemption will be continued? (Time expired)

—Let me make it quite clear that the only hopeless shambles that we have seen in this Senate chamber is the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party were defeated profoundly last night. They have fought against tax reform for 15 years and last night the Senate decided to move ahead with tax reform. So, Senator Schacht, the only shambles in this place is the Labor Party. The strategy of the leaders of the Labor Party was to avoid any major policy change and just go for the politics of sleaze and the big lie. That is what the Labor Party approach was.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. I asked a question about the arrangements with the South Australian government. The minister has not yet got anywhere near to answering it. We would just like to know: have you reached agreement with the South Australian government on the $300,000 exemption?
—Senator Kemp, I draw your attention to the question asked by Senator Schacht.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was referring to the point in the question about shambles. It was not me who raised the issue of shambles, it was Senator Schacht. I was pointing out that if he wants to raise the issue of shambles, the biggest shambles in this parliament is the Australian Labor Party, their leadership and their utter failure of strategy. It is no wonder at all that we are already seeing discussions in the press about the security of the tenure of leadership of Mr Beazley. I might say that I would not be surprised if we saw discussions about—

—Madam President, I take a point of order. This is the second time that I draw your attention to relevance. The minister has not got anywhere near answering the question regarding whether there is an agreement with South Australia on a $300,000 exemption for wineries, which is a very important question for South Australia.

—Part of the problem of course is that there was comment within the question. I think Senator Kemp knows what the question is, but he is also dealing with the comment. However, I draw your attention to the question, Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Madam President. You are quite right: if a question is worded in that manner, I have the right to answer the question in a way which deals with the matters that you have raised. Regrettably, you blundered again. You raised the issue of shambles and that opened the whole area to a discussion about the performance of the Labor Party. In relation to the issue that Senator Schacht raised regarding a comment made by the Treasurer, I will check with him and inform the Senate in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, when you are checking with the Treasurer, would you ask him: is it true that the 29 per cent wine equalisation tax plus the GST will increase the wine industry's tax impost by 12 per cent, or $147 million, and make Australia the most highly taxed wine producing country in the world?

—Let me make it clear that the WET tax means that, after the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and its replacement with the GST, prices will be equalised to avoid dramatic and dislocating price falls. The government has consulted industry and taken advice from it in formulating the WET tax. Senator Schacht has asked me to raise matters with the Treasurer, and I will do so.

—My question, which is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, follows on from the historic passing of the new tax system yesterday in this chamber. Will the minister advise the Senate what benefits will flow to Australians from the passing of the tax package?

—I thank Senator Lightfoot for his question. Senator Lightfoot, along with every senator on this side of the chamber, has been very strongly supportive of tax reform. As I indicated in my earlier remarks today, yesterday was a very historic day as the goods and services tax bills and related bills passed through this chamber and went to the other place. I think it is widely recognised that the Australian public voted for tax reform and the Australian public have got tax reform. I think the group in the community that are hopelessly exposed now are the Labor Party, as the Labor Party have nowhere to go. The Labor Party have no policies on tax reform. Their only policy was to oppose, oppose and oppose. What we will see in the coming weeks will be the public asking the Labor Party where they stand on tax reform. The public will ask whether they will restore the wholesale sales tax of which they are so beloved. The fact of the matter is that, if they want to restore the wholesale sales tax, all they have to do is repeal the bills which have gone through the parliament and bring in a new bill to restore the wholesale sales tax.

answer.para: I am pleased to say that on 1 July 2000, the government will be able to deliver the largest income tax cuts in Australian history with the introduction of a new tax system. Small business people, factory workers, teachers, shop owners and tradespeople all deserve, and will now get, a major income tax cut. Along with the restructure of the tax system, the new tax system will provide very generous benefits to Australians, including massive cuts in income tax totalling some $12 billion. In fact, a typical Australian family may well receive in the order of $40 to $50 a week in tax cuts as a result of this package that passed through the Senate last night. There will be massive tax cuts and massive help to Australian families. In the package there is additional assistance available to families worth some $2.5 billion and, of course, there are real rises in pensions and benefits. It is one of the astonishing features of the debate—and history will record this—that the Labor Party opposed massive cuts in taxation. The Labor Party opposed a massive rise in assistance to families. The Labor Party opposed real rises in pensions and benefits.

This is about the fourth time in the last decade and a half to two decades that either the Labor Party or the coalition has tried to achieve this type of tax reform. The good news is that on 1 July 2000 it will become a reality and we can consign Australia's current outdated and ramshackle system to the pages of Australian history. This reform had to pass many obstacles before it passed the Senate, but the major obstacle was the Australian Labor Party which, for reasons best known to itself, decided to set its face against tax reform. Now the Australian public want to know what the Labor Party does stand for, what the Labor Party will do in the area of tax reform. It has only had four years to work out a solution to this problem and we are all waiting to hear it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister advise what obstacles the tax reform package has had to overcome?

—I think the biggest obstacle, as I indicated, was the Australian Labor Party. It is quite amazing that the Labor Party simply has not been able to work out a clear position on tax reform, except to oppose changes which were originally developed by the government and then negotiated with the Democrats. The Labor Party's only position has been to oppose tax reform. I have always said that the hardest question that anyone can ask in this parliament is: what does the Labor Party stand for? No-one knows the answer to the question. I do not know the answer to the question and the Labor Party does not know the answer to that question.

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Minister, is it true that to date traditional owner opposition to the construction of a road for the transportation of ore from the Jabiluka mine to the Ranger mill has prevented ERA's preferred option of milling at Ranger from going ahead? Since clause 387(2)(b) of the Howard-Lees environment legislation allows the transportation of anything—no matter how dangerous—through Kakadu, doesn't this make traditional owner consent irrelevant? By agreeing to this clause, haven't the Democrats made a nonsense of their claimed opposition to the Ranger mill alternative?

—It is a novel argument which I will have a look at afterwards. It certainly was not the intention but, if the senator is suggesting that it has that effect, we will look at it and see what flows therefrom. The point is that traditional owners have resisted the milling of ore taken from Jabiluka mine at the existing Ranger site. That is a matter of great regret. Everyone acknowledges that it would be better to process the ore from Jabiluka in the existing plant. I would have thought that was obvious not only to indigenous Australians but to all Australians. The advantages are, obviously, that you do not need to build a new plant out at the Jabiluka site and you do not need a road for that purpose between the two sites. Unfortunately, approval has not been given for the milling at Ranger to date.
—Are you the minister for destroying the environment?

—You miss the point, Senator Schacht. The point I am making is that if consent was given for milling at Ranger, you would achieve a better environmental outcome. Ranger was the mine that the Labor Party oversaw for 13 years while in government. A large open-cut uranium mine already existed which apparently was not a threat to the environment at all. The current debate is whether a small, new, underground mine a few kilometres away is fundamentally different. Of course it is not fundamentally different.
