How could Labor say for 13 years—even you would have trouble answering this, Senator Schacht—that Ranger was not a threat to the environment and then, all of a sudden, Jabiluka is a fundamental threat—Jabiluka, with a footprint of just over one square kilometre, is a threat to a national park of 20,000 square kilometres? That is how illogical the Labor argument is on this matter. It is true that consents have not been given. Consents will need to be given by traditional owners in order to process at Ranger. Without those consents that processing cannot take place.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Was it the case that such matters as transportation of ore previously had to be approved through express provision in the Kakadu plan of management, thus giving the Kakadu board a power of veto? Since the Howard-Lees deal proceeded without consultation with stakeholders, whose rights have now been taken away, isn't the Director of the Jawoyn Association, Mr Robert Lee, correct when he says that his people feel like jacky-jackys?

—The rights of nobody have been taken away. Some of us actually believe in representative democracy and that this parliament has the power to pass laws and that they apply to all Australians. Some of us think that a period of 2½ years of consultation is sufficient. Some of us think that 11 months within a parliamentary inquiry is adequate—considered for 11 months by this parliament in its committees of inquiry. Some people think that that is a good basis for making law in this country. That is what true democracy is all about and nobody has been disenfranchised.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Minister, will you advise the Senate as to what the government has done to improve the integrity and the fairness of the social security system? Could the minister also advise the Senate as to what changes are due to come into effect as of 1 July, and include any crackdowns that are going to occur which will provide further funds for increased payments to those in real need?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Knowles for the question. As chairman of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee she has a continuing and in-depth interest in these subjects. It is important for the Senate to acknowledge and to recognise that there are a wide range of initiatives, in my portfolio area in particular, starting from 1 July. For example, 14,000 carers of adult relatives who previously were not eligible for assistance will now be able to receive a carer allowance because of a liberalisation of the entitlement. That will cost the Australian taxpayer $92 million over the next four years. It is obviously something which needs to be done for those carers.

answer.para: Carer allowance and carer payment will be able to be claimed for up to 63 days when the child or the care recipient is in hospital, as well as for up to 63 days when that person is in respite care, as is presently the case. So there is another 63 days if the person being cared for has to go to hospital. It is obviously a practical and a necessary measure. Foster carers, who I think are the salt of the earth in this country, are going to be able to receive a health care card which gives them access to the cheaper pharmaceuticals and other concessions for the child which they currently have not been able to access. Also, there will no longer be a 12-month waiting period for single foster carers to access the parenting payment.

There are going to be more flexible arrangements for non-custodial parents when making payments outside the Child Support Agency and they will be able to be considered as part of their child support liabilities. I am thinking there about things like school fees, medical expenses, et cetera. There will be $9 million going to community organisations to provide support networks for men in their family relationships and $6 million to community organisations to provide marriage and relationship education.

There will be new trial funding arrangements for disability employment assistance. And, for example, Age Pension News is now going to be distributed to those self-funded retirees who are eligible for the Commonwealth seniors health card. We expect that, over time, up to 220,000 additional older Australians will be eligible both for the Commonwealth seniors health card and for the Age Pension News.

Senator Knowles spoke about compliance measures. Twenty Centrelink offices are going to be located in Australian tax offices to help stop fraud and increase compliance. That is where some of the money will be able to be accessed to do these very necessary things for people in need. There will be data matching of Centrelink records with state and territory superannuation administration authorities, with the Australian Stock Exchange and the Registrar-General's offices—Births, Deaths and Marriages—so that we can identify customers who may not have provided the correct information about their children, their superannuation or their shareholdings.

We are expanding the mutual obligation scheme to people aged 25 to 34 who have been unemployed for 12 months. That is going to include Work for the Dole, literacy and numeracy skills and the other list of measures as previously announced. It is interesting that the Labor spokesman Martin Ferguson now supports the Work for the Dole scheme. It is quite fascinating. He has finally given recognition that the scheme works and that it leads to real jobs for young Australians. He tries to make a suggestion or two about what else we could do for young people. He fails to acknowledge that the youth allowance is exactly filling the gap that he says needs filling. Youth allowance is allowing young people to be in part-time work and improving their skills at the same time as getting youth allowance. That is an important recognition of the reality of young people's lives. This government stands for good policy development and the vacuum on the other side is deafening. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My further question to the minister is the all important question about income streams for retirees. I understand that there are further changes to be made in that area. Could the minister please explain to the Senate what those changes will be?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. That is a question asking the government to make a statement about government policy, which is expressly forbidden under the standing orders. You should rule it out of order.
—A statement of government intention is permissible.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —In looking forward to the coming year, as I have been doing in my answer, it is pretty important to also recognise what has been done in the past year.
—Senator Cook should be interested in retirement income.

—Senator Cook might be interested in retirement income if we could only encourage him to be brave and step outside. It is interesting that only yesterday the chairman of the Australian Retirement Income Streams Association, Mr Kieren Dell, pointed out that retirees are being encouraged to move away from lump sums and into income streams through a sensible and positive policy approach developed by the federal government. There is recognition that good policy development is continuously coming from this government and the absence of it from the opposition is a matter of great sadness to the Australian people because an alternative government they are not and never will be until they too start focusing on policy development. It will be the measure by which they are judged. (Time expired)

—I address my question to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Does the minister recall Senator Lees's statement last week that Kakadu would now `look much like a piece of Swiss cheese, with no less than 23 active mining leases'? Is it true that clause 359(3) of the Howard-Lees environment bill allows the minister to renew such leases without either environmental assessment or the consent of traditional owners?

—I am surprised that someone from the Labor Party would have the nerve to ask that question. The leases have returned to be leases because of a mistake of the Australian Labor Party in government. The ALP sought to incorporate the leases within the park but forgot to pay just terms compensation. The matter was taken to the court and it was found that what the Labor Party did was invalid, regrettably. I would have thought, Senator Reynolds, that you might have acknowledged your participation in the cause of the problem.

answer.para: Having received the problem from the Labor Party, we have to address it. As I have said in this chamber, it is our intention to reincorporate the leases within the park but to do it in a constitutional way. That means that we have got to meet the responsibility of just terms, and we have been seeking to assess what those just terms would mean in the case of those leases. As I said the other day—obviously the honourable senator missed the debate—it is a complex issue, because the judgment, which you may or may not have read, actually did not make clear which were the leases to which it applied, and considerable work has had to be done since then to determine the leases. Then considerable work has got to be done to try and assess what their value is. That work, as I indicated, is ongoing, and when we have answers on that we will be able to complete the process of reincorporation of the leases within the park. I would have thought that would be something that Senator Reynolds would applaud and I would think that she would congratulate the government for correcting the error that the Labor Party made.

talk.start.para: —I think it is a little early for congratulations, Minister. I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Isn't it true that clause 359(6), which purports to protect Kakadu National Park, is of no effect with respect to these 23 leases since the High Court in the Newcrest case determined that the national park did not cover the 23 leases? Isn't this confirmed by the advice from the Australian Government Solicitor, which confirms that the leases, including Ranger 44 on the flood plain west of Jabiluka, are active and could be exploited?

—I know that this failed to get a run the other day and it is probably thought to be worth giving it another go, but, regrettably, the Labor Party created the problem that we are seeking to fix. I do not know how many times I need say it but I will repeat it again: we will correct Labor's error by reincorporating the leases within the park and meeting our responsibility under the terms of the Australian Constitution. That will reassure Australians that the park will not suffer as a result of Labor's error. I do not know how many times I need to say it. If I were in the Australian Labor Party, I would be a touch too embarrassed to raise that matter in here.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of a statement of opposition from 32 eminent Australians and the Democrats to the government's proposed so-called voluntary student unionism legislation? Has the minister read today's Canberra Times editorial, which highlights the absurdity of the legislation in treating student unions as trade unions? Does the minister believe that student unions are trade unions? Finally, given the widespread and diverse opposition to the legislation from the community and the higher education sector, why is the minister persisting with this legislation?

—Answering the last part of Senator Stott Despoja's question first, it is quite easy to explain why we are persisting with this. It is a matter of policy, and one which we have stood by for some years. It deals with the basic concept of voluntary association, one which you will find like a thread running through Liberal philosophy. That is why we are supporting it. We are supporting it on the basis that students should not be compelled to join any association, that they should be free to do so. I am aware of the article yesterday. I am also aware of false reports that we are shelving this legislation. Far from it. In fact, I think the Prime Minister was on Triple J today saying that we would stand by this legislation and that he could not understand those people who did not agree with the principle of voluntary association. I found a lot of support for the principle of voluntary association. NUS has described itself as a union, and to use that term `union' is not inappropriate. We are talking about a form of compulsory unionism where students do not get a choice. What we are saying to the students of Australia and the people of Australia is that we are a government that stands for freedom.
—What about the Law Society? You can't practise without membership.
—What about rugby union?
—Order! Senators on my left are being disruptive and disorderly, and are behaving in breach of the standing orders.

—As I said, this cannot be likened to something like local government or the provision of student services. NUS has described its primary goal as the provision of union services to students across Australia. What we are talking about here is compelling students to join an association—no fee, no degree. That is the underlying problem with this concept, because it is compelling students to join an association that they do not wish to join.

answer.para: In Western Australia, we have voluntary student unionism. We have seen there that student services do not decline. I would say to those people who signed that advertisement yesterday, `Go back and have a look at Western Australia and the student services that are being provided to students.' I would also asked them to bear in mind that what we are about is voluntary association. I am sure that once those people understood what this policy means, they would be withdrawing their stance on this issue.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to know if the minister considers student unions trade unions. Does the minister agree with Minister Kemp's description of supporters of student organisations—that is, that they are union lap-dogs? Would he dare describe in that way His Eminence Cardinal Clancy, Ms Janet Holmes a Court or Mr John Platten? In light of the support of a cardinal, two bishops, a rugby player—Joe Roff—on this petition, will the minister—

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections. I draw senators' attention to the standing orders and the requirements of them.
—In light of the support of a cardinal, two bishops and a rugby player, will the minister be taking action to outlaw communion, rugby union and marital union?

—You only have to look at the NUS, who describe themselves as a union. They have said it themselves. They have described themselves as a union. Madam President, you do not have to go any further than that. Senator Stott Despoja would like to see students across Australia compulsorily pay an up-front fee in excess of $300. That is what this is all about. Once again, I say for the record that we are about voluntary association—and that is not just in the sphere of student unionism, it is across the board. We are a party of voluntary association and freedom of choice. Those are the basic tenets of our belief and that is what we went to the people of Australia with last year in October, and those are the tenets and principles upon which we won.

—My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister advise the Senate what effect the collapse of the negotiations between the government and that highly respected trade union the AMA about new payments for general practitioners will have on the budget for the Department of Health and Aged Care? Will the payment to GPs in the 1999 budget for coordinated care planning, multidisciplinary case conferencing, voluntary assessments for over-75s, and reten tion payments for rural GPs still proceed without the agreement with GPs being signed?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Forshaw for the question. Being a Fellow of the Australian Medical Association, I should state my interest in this—and I am proud member. It is not a union. It is a voluntary association. We do not have to belong.
—Order! I have already drawn the Senate's attention to the requirements of the standing orders and I ask that senators behave in accordance with them.

—In Australia, 26,000 doctors voluntarily put in their fees to be part of that. Of 40,000 doctors, 26,000 proudly belong to the Australian Medical Association. They are not coerced—not like all those people on the other side who have to be members of unions and members of the Labor Party to be in the Senate. They have no choice. They warm the benches over there representing nobody but their own unions. They are all representing unions. I am proud to say that there are members of unions on this side.
—Order! The behaviour at present is in breach of the standing orders and senators are disregarding the orders of the chair—which is also in breach of the standing orders.
—Madam President, you will have to forgive them because it is near the end of the Senate term and one gets a bit concerned.
—What's your excuse?

—The same—it is the same, Senator Ray. The government has been negotiating with general practitioners to try to develop a financial agreement which will improve financial certainty for both the profession and the government.
—You've found the brief, have you?

—Senator Faulkner, I have had it all the time. More importantly, it will promote quality care for patients. A draft memorandum of understanding was finalised on 21 May with the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Rural Doctors Association of Australia and the Australian Divisions of General Practice.

—Senator Schacht probably does not realise that they are all members of the AMA; it just happens that they are in separate divisions. Senator Forshaw may be interested to know that the offer is still on the table. Dr Wooldridge understands that the AMA has its own internal issues at the moment which it is discussing, and he is happy to continue to discuss the issues with general practitioners and general practitioner groups who wish to talk to him. The government is prepared to invest additional money in the Medicare system in return for cooperation from general practitioners in increasing the quality of services and the cost effectiveness of expenditure.

answer.para: A memorandum of understanding would give us the framework inside which we could modernise the Medicare schedule and deliver better quality care to patients—something that did not occur during 13 years of Labor Party government when they had no intention to do anything about it and tried to destroy private medical practice. This is designed to increase the quality of care, to cut down six-minute medicine, and to increase the quality of care for patients right throughout Australia.

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for his lengthy consultation but he did not actually answer the question, which was directed to whether the payments would still proceed if the agreement was not signed. So I would ask you to take that part of it on notice and respond later, Minister. But I have a supplementary question and that is: how will the $297 million in net cuts to pathology and pharmaceutical expenditure be achieved without the cooperation of the GPs? Isn't it the case that the health budget is now in a shambles as a result of the minister for health's inability to negotiate an agreement?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw shows his abysmal lack of understanding of the whole system with that statement. It is not only general practitioners that order pathology tests; Senator Forshaw premised his supplementary question on the assumption that that was so. Senator Forshaw should be aware that half the profession are specialists and order pathology tests recurrently. He does not even understand the question. I think he should redraft his question so that he can get the answer that he is looking for. The reality is that negotiations will continue when the Australian Medical Association sorts out their internal difficulties—as they will. They will sort out their internal difficulties. They are not as rabble-roused and divided as the ALP is at this moment over their own leadership. We keep reading about the disunity in the Labor Party and the factions that are occurring at the moment as to their future. I can assure you that the AMA will sort out their problems. (Time expired)
—Order! I think there are some senators who have forgotten the wording of standing order 203 and I suggest that they read it.

subdebateinfo.title: Tax Reform: Information Technology and Telecommunications Industry

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Minister, the passage of the tax package demonstrates again that the coalition has a plan and hopes for Australia's future. Will the minister inform the Senate how this historic initiative will benefit Australian consumers and business? Will the minister advise the Senate of the IT&T industry reaction to the package?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Macdonald for what may well be his last question in this place, at least for the time being. It is a very important question because it goes to the heart of the changes that have just been put through the Senate in both a historic and a heroic manner by Senator Kemp. What it does is ensure that the new tax system will be a huge boost to the IT&T industry and of course, if ever there was a growth sector in Australia—indeed around the world—this has got to be it. So it is critically important that we have significant benefits to Australian consumers and business users of IT&T products.

answer.para: Under Labor's inconsistent raft of wholesale sales taxes, computers, printers, keyboards and other IT&T communications equipment are currently slugged with a tax rate of 22 per cent or higher. Indeed cameras, televisions, videos, projectors and stereos are rated at 32 per cent. Clearly these items will be vastly cheaper under the new tax regime. Of course the GST will replace all of these inconsistent and contradictory rates with a tax rate of 10 per cent. Lower tax rates obviously allow lower prices to consumers and mean improved access to IT&T equipment and consequently a greater ability to access the online environment and all the products and services that it has to offer.

It is particularly gratifying that the industry reaction has been very positive. I single out for special mention the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, who welcomed the package, saying that it would make Australian exports more competitive. Indeed, they also have a view on Labor's general approach to taxation reform. They said at the time:
Labor's package is focused on taxing products and leaves services alone. This places a huge burden on the shrinking manufacturing sector—services are a much larger part of the economy.

It is therefore very significant indeed that the AEEMA is now to be headed up by Mr Beazley's former chief of staff, Mr David Epstein. Of course not only is Mr Epstein jumping off a sinking ship, but he is joining an organisation that has both endorsed the coalition's specific approach to tax and also of course very heavily bagged Labor's approach to tax. He joins a growing rank of senior ALP figures who once they actually get into the real world have a very different view. So I was amazed this morning to read that Mr Beazley was out there doing a doorstop saying:

The Australian agenda needs to be about the security our people need in the next century and how we build the knowledge-based society, because only knowledge-based societies are going to be competitive in the next century. And these tax changes have nothing to do with that.

Well, as they say in the industry, he just doesn't get it. These are the tools of the trade that you need to be successful in the information economy, and Mr Beazley is locked in to 22 and 32 per cent rates. If there were one single thing you could do, it would be to reduce the cost of these items. I am astounded that people like Senator Lundy have not been making that point very heavily to the current Leader of the Opposition, because clearly he needs as much help as he can get on a whole range of fronts but particularly if he is going to rabbit on about the knowledge based economy. If he thinks he can get through to the next election with a few nice words on the subject, then he has also got to explain why he is in favour of a much higher rate of payment on the retail prices of many of these items in the IT&T sector. So here is another very good learning opportunity for the Labor Party: go back and look at what is happening in the real world, take notice of all those people like Bob Hogg, Gary Johns and even Mr Della Bosca, who seems to think you ought to be positive for a change, and you might actually come up with some policies that work.

subdebateinfo.title: Bringing Them Home Report: National Response

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the Commonwealth government has delegated the responsibility to coordinate a national response to the Bringing them Home report to the Victorian government? Is it true that this decision was taken in August 1998? Can the minister confirm that there has not been a single meeting of the working group which Victoria was to coordinate? In view of Victoria's lack of interest in fulfilling its delegated responsibility, will the government now do what it should have done in the first place and take over the chair of the working group?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The coordination of the Bringing them home report is under the control of ATSIC. A lot of work has gone on since the Bringing them home report was brought down. The government has provided ATSIC with $11.25 million over four years to establish a dedicated indigenous family tracing and reunion service, known as the Link-Up service, in each state and the Northern Territory. As a first step, ATSIC was required to commission an independent evaluation of the existing services to identify the most appropriate models, including the resources required in each jurisdiction for new and enhanced services. That evaluation was completed in April this year.

answer.para: In the interim, existing services have been funded at historic levels. Contemporaneously with the evaluation, ATSIC has progressed the government's decision through funding established Link-Up services in New South Wales, Tasmania, Victoria and Queensland to employ additional caseworkers. Provision of specialist family tracing planning and purchase of capital items such as computer hardware and software have also occurred, which will enhance the Link-Up services family tracing efforts. Submissions from organisations wishing to establish dedicated Link-Up services in Western Australia and South Australia have gone out to enhance the services in the Northern Territory also, and they are being developed.

Contemporaneously with the evaluation of Link-Up, ATSIC started a number of tasks aimed at implementing the government's decision relating to that national Link-Up network. That included the development of a position paper for ATSIC's negotiations with the states and territories on matters such as state responses to the Bringing them home report and access to records and relevant mainstream and indigenous services. This has involved ascertaining the current and planned situation in each state and territory. I presume that Senator Carr's question was related to the Victorian aspect of that which, as I said, is being linked together by ATSIC in any case.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it the case that the Victorian government has been delegated the responsibility to coordinate a national response? I ask the minister to address that question directly. I further ask: is it also true that the Victorian government has yet to even nominate personnel who are to act as consultants to this working group? If it is the case, why is it that the minister and the government are displaying such a lack of interest by allowing this to go on for so long?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Far from displaying a lack of interest, I have continually monitored this. As I said, ATSIC has been responsible for the conduct of the responses from the states and territories, and I will ask ATSIC to bring me up to date today in response to Senator Carr's question. Personnel is the responsibility of the Victorian section, and I will get back to Senator Carr when I have the names.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and relates to that dreadful action by the Australian government of sending a woman 8½ months pregnant back to certain forced abortion. I ask the minister: precisely what action has been taken to ensure the undertakings given by the Chinese authorities that the woman would not be forcibly sterilised, that all the family planning fines and abortion costs would be waived and that she would be found a job and accommodation for her and her three-year-old daughter? How are these undertakings being monitored? Can the minister provide to the Senate an up-to-date account of how the woman is and whether these monitoring activities are going to continue until that person is safe?

—I thank the senator for his question. I can see by looking at the very limited brief I have on this matter that it does not go specifically to the points you raise, so I propose to give you the information that I have on the understanding that I recognise it does not address specifically the points you raise and that I will raise them with Mr Ruddock and get you an answer as soon as I possibly can on the matters not covered by this information. The brief that I have does raise generally the question of the safety of the woman referred to. It says:

answer.para: The government is satisfied with the arrangements which have been made by the Chinese government for her resettlement in China.
We are assured that she faces no threat from the Chinese authorities, nor does she have any outstanding debts to the Chinese government.

As you know, Senator, an independent inquiry into her removal from Australia is being undertaken by Mr Tony Ayers. Until that has been completed, we will not be offering comments on the matters covered by the terms of reference. I am advised that her application for an Australian visa is under consideration, and I am also advised that she can contact the Australian Consulate in Guangzhou at any time if she so wishes. Our discussion with Chinese authorities on this issue, I am advised, has been very positive. I am further advised that, if Mr Ayers needs to interview her, we will seek to make appropriate arrangements for him to do so. I will refer any further matters in your particular question that have not been answered by that to Mr Ruddock and get an answer for you as soon as I am able to.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will not say what my current information is, but it is clearly far more advanced than the minister's. I ask very specifically for the minister to come back into this chamber either today or tomorrow and outline to the chamber which consular officials have seen the woman in the last two weeks. What is the report of her condition at the present moment and the undertakings that were given by the Chinese authorities? In respect of the lady concerned, is the government going to provide a temporary visa for her to come to Australia to give evidence to that inquiry, under other inquiries that are being continued, including that by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee?

—Senator, as I indicated, I understood from the very beginning that the brief I had did not answer all the points that you raised. I indicated that I would get on to Mr Ruddock and get an answer from him as soon as I could, and I will do that. If the Hansard pinks show further questions raised in your supplementary, I will get them answered as well. I have just seen from the back of the prepared brief that the information that I have given you was prepared on 21 June. So it was prepared last week. There may be further information from that point on, and I will get it for you as soon as I can.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware that, of the 31,800 new health insurance policies taken out in the first quarter of this year, only 2,712 were for full cover? Is the minister concerned that there is a rapidly growing number of people with exclusionary policies with large up-front payments who are taking out the cheapest possible insurance simply to avoid paying the Medicare surcharge?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam President, it is the old ALP question again: force everybody into something—compulsion. We are about freedom of choice. If people want to take out the cover that they so desire, so be it. We are not forcing them to do anything. The Labor Party wants to socialise medicine. That is all it is interested in: socialising medicine and forcing people to take compulsory cover. We have set out a comprehensive and strategic approach to allow people freedom of choice so that we can maintain the balance between the public hospital system and the private hospital system. If people take up-front cover—they might go for cover under which they will accept the first $1,000 of cost of their hospital care—so be it. That is called freedom. The Labor Party would not understand that. It is called freedom of choice. They can take out whichever cover is available.

answer.para: The government has adopted this approach so that it can maintain that balance. All the Labor Party is interested in is a public hospital system with no freedom of choice for Australians to take out whatever cover they desire. If people are taking out that cover, so be it; they are entitled to do that. It is a competitive market. We are moving towards a system where we will have a supplemented private health sector that is fair, affordable, customer friendly and good value for money. It is up to the individual to decide which cover they take out. The introduction of a lifetime health cover scheme, the 30 per cent rebate, the pursuit of reforms to address the gap and the development of coordinated care in the private sector are all part of a cohesive approach to address these objectives. Where is the Labor Party's health policy? Madam President, there is silence from the other side—a policy vacuum. I accused them of trying to socialise health care, and they all shouted in agreement. I asked them what their policy was—silence; dead silence.

talk.start.para: —Senator Herron, I would point out that to shout back at you would be disorderly.

—It is fairly obvious that what we are doing is part of a comprehensive strategy to maintain that balance between the private and the public hospital systems and give people a choice dependent on their financial resources. We need to encourage young people back into the system because of the community rating principle, which we support, and we will continue to do so. But obviously, with the ageing population, there have to be measures taken to keep that quantum of money going into the private hospital system at a high level; otherwise it goes bust, and it is not our intention for that to occur. If people are exercising their freedom of choice to take out this level of private health insurance, we welcome them in, because the alternative is that they would be totally reliant on the public hospital system, which is already overcrowded and run down by the 13 years that the Labor Party was in power—leaving us with a system that will go further down the drain unless active measures are taken.
—You weren't reading your brief. You've been told not to do that.
—Senator Faulkner, you are behaving in a disorderly fashion.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if the Medicare surcharge artificially boosts the number of people with private health insurance, how will this relieve pressure on the public hospital system, given that these people will still use a public hospital if they get sick because they face a large front-end payment plus all the gap repayments?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Obviously Senator Gibbs does not know the quantum of money that goes into the hospital system under the government sector. Private hospitals get $295 million out of each Commonwealth budget. Public hospitals, on the other hand, get $5,181 million. So the premise on which that supplementary question is asked is false. The other balance, of course, goes into the repatriation hospitals—$16 million a year. The quantum is $5,181 million compared to $295 million. So to allege that somehow this tiny little change is going to make the public hospital system grind to a halt is false. I suggest that Senator Gibbs go back to the questions committee and get somebody in the Labor Party to spend a little time trying to understand the hospital system of this country. I will nominate Senator Chris Evans. He is obviously on the rise and trying to make a name for himself.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer to the urgent need for accommodation for people with disabilities and the ongoing failure of the federal government to reach agreement with the states on disabilities funding. I ask: does the minister recall her answer to my question back in April in which she said:

question.para: It is now up to negotiations between the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to work out the degree of that sharing.
Again I ask: is the minister seriously pursuing the matter of unmet need? What negotiations have taken place in the last three months on supported accommodation funding?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Allison is that of course this government takes this matter of unmet need very seriously, which is why the ministerial council meeting which was held in May, I think, agreed between the governments that there was a shared role and responsibility for all governments to address the need of people with disabilities for accommodation, respite and similar services—need that has been growing for something like two decades. People in the disabilities area have made it very clear that they do not see that it is going to be met overnight. It has taken a long time to develop, and it will take a long time to be addressed. Nevertheless, I have been watching very closely and with interest the state government budgets to see what the state governments are prepared to commit into the future in an area for which, under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement, the major part of the responsibility falls to the states and has done since the disability agreement was negotiated in 1991 and continued in the agreement negotiated by my predecessor, the Hon. Warwick Smith.

answer.para: Some state and territory governments have begun to recognise their responsibilities to share the problem of unmet need, as we agreed at the recent ministers meeting. The ACT government has announced funding of a further $1 million each year for disability services in recognition of the unmet need in that area. The Victorian government has also announced an additional $5 million for community based accommodation, associated day programs and training programs for people with disabilities in the budget they handed down on 4 May. On 6 May the Western Australian budget committed $151.7 million for this coming year, which is similar to the level of funds that was declared under the second Commonwealth-state disability agreement. On 27 May the South Australian government budget announced an additional $3.3 million to ensure that services for people with disabilities are maintained. It has not been announced which portion of this money will be distributed through the Commonwealth-state disability agreement. I do not yet have an analysis of the New South Wales budget in terms of disabilities but, from what I have noticed in the press, I am a bit disappointed that accommodation services are being closed down—it is claimed with a saving of something of the order of $12½ million, which I believe is to go back to the state Treasury. That does not sound very positive.

I do expect that states are going to show further commitment to addressing unmet need down the track. The Commonwealth will be making an additional contribution over and above our budget commitment later this year on the basis that the states and territories also make significant contributions. I would say, however, that it is very unfortunate when all governments sign on to a communique that perhaps it is not read more closely by those who would assess what was the outcome of a ministerial council meeting. I am very disappointed that some organisations have in fact assumed that the Commonwealth is standing aside from this process—nothing could be further from the truth. It is easy to frighten people or to whip up thinking that there is no cooperation. I would compare the ministerial council meeting on the unmet need in the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program for homeless people with the ministerial council meeting on people with disabilities. Their cooperation in terms of the homeless I think has been very much warmer and more progressive. I would like to see that sort of relationship in dealing with what has been a serious and endemic problem, as you know yourself, Senator.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. She has outlined the budgets of some of the states. I ask, as I did three months ago, what is the federal government's offer to the states in this respect and when will there be agreement? I am glad the minister also referred to the New South Wales incident of the privatisation of 200 group homes for people with intellectual disabilities. Was this discussed at the ministerial council meeting? How does privatisation help meet the unmet needs of people with disabilities in New South Wales? What guarantees are there that the privatisation of group homes will not lead to even greater abuse of people with disabilities in that state?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —As Senator Allison would know, the provision of accommodation services under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement is a matter for the states. The issue of the changes to the arrangements in New South Wales were not discussed, and I am not a party to their activity.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Senator Schacht today asked me a question in relation to a statement that Mr Costello had made. I wish to add to my answer. I refer Senator Schacht to the fact that Mr Costello answered a very similar question to the one he raised in the other place on 24 June. I refer Senator Schacht to that particular answer.
—I seek leave to incorporate a further answer to the supplementary question asked by Senator Bartlett of Senator Minchin, representing me, yesterday.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Bartlett asked the Minister, representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Minchin, the following supplementary question on 28 June 1999:

Could the Minister outline to the Senate in what ways the options outlined in the directions paper actually meet adequate fauna habitat protection standards? The RFA is supposed to provide comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for forest protection. Will the government make available statistics on species and habitat, as well as regional ecosystems and alternative employment options, to ensure that the community assess adequately and accurately that the requirement for adequate protection of the south-east Queensland forests is met?
Senator Hill— The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:
The Commonwealth remains committed to achieving balanced RFA outcomes in SEQ and recognises the diverse range of conservation values that require protection.

During 1997 and 1998, the Commonwealth and Queensland governments conducted a comprehensive assessment of the full range of social, economic, environment and heritage values in the South East Queensland Forest estate, making available the best information ever collected about the region's forests, including about species and habitat.

Information on species in South East Queensland is summarised in the Comprehensive Regional Assessment, publicly released on 18 March 1999. Detailed species information collected through the projects outlined in the Comprehensive Regional Assessment have also been publicly available on that date, including on the Commonwealth RFA Internet site www.rfa.gov.au.

The knowledge gained through the Comprehensive Regional Assessment, process was integrated to develop the scenarios outlined in the Directions Report `Towards a South-East Queensland Regional Forest Agreement' , released on 14 May 1999. The Directions Report summarises the current economic, social and conservation situation in South East Queensland and, as a basis for public comment, presents a range of indicative scenarios that illustrate strategic issues that arise in developing a possible regional forest agreement.
Species information collected as part of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment will be used by governments in the developing of the conservation outcomes for the Regional Forest Agreement.

talk.start.para: —Secondly, I have some further information to an answer I gave today to Senator Crossin, regarding the road in the Kakadu region. Having looked at the law briefly, it would seem that Senator Crossin is wrong. Clause 387 of the new bill being passed into law at the moment does not prevent the requirement for any traditional owner consent in relation to the milling of ore at Ranger. In addition, clause 387, to which she refers, merely continues in force the following provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, in particular subsection 10(1A), subsection 10(1B) and subsection 3A—that is, clause 387 does not change the law or take away any rights. The most relevant of those provisions—that is, corresponding with the NPWC Act—is clause 3A, which was in fact introduced by the ALP in 1987.

—I also have some further information in relation to the question from Senator Reynolds. The answer to Senator Reynolds's question is similar, so obviously the questions have been written by the same person. Sena tor Reynolds referred to clause 359(3) and (6). The clauses are equivalent to section 8B in the NPWC Act—in other words, there is no change in the law. Again, section 8B was amended to be in its present form by the ALP in 1987—that is, it merely continued in force.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Rural and Regional Australia

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I seek to make an explanation of an answer I gave yesterday, pursuant to standing order 191.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is not needed under standing order 191.
—I am not sure that 191 is the appropriate standing order. I think, for what you said you wanted to do, you would need leave of the Senate.
—I want to explain a speech that I made yesterday, namely, an answer to a question. It relates to the—
—That relates to a speech, not a personal explanation, I think, Senator.

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will cease shouting.
—Madam President, it relates to a publication, Inside Canberra , which Senator Mackay mentioned yesterday. The author of that magazine has asked me—
—Senator, as I understand it, that was in a question yesterday.
—That is right; it was in my answer, which is a speech.
—It is an answer to a question, which is not the same as a speech, Senator.
—Madam President, I simply want to make a statement about that but, if the Senate does not want me to, Mr Chalmers can thank the Labor Party for it.
—Is leave granted for Senator Ian Macdonald to make a statement?
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I do not, obviously, question your ruling. I think Senator Ian Macdonald is adding to his answer of yesterday, which was in relation to a speech.
—That was not what he said.
—Therefore, for that he would not seek leave.

—Madam President, on the same point of order: it may well be the case that Senator Ian Macdonald wishes to add to an answer, which is in order after question time and for which I do not believe he needs to seek leave, but I would respectfully suggest to you that that is not what he said when he rose to his feet and addressed you—and I think you ruled properly that it was not competent for him to do so. But if he now realises the error of his ways and he wants to do something else, it is not within the capacity of the opposition to stop him, but we do note that this is all eating into time for taking note of answers prior to the guillotine applying at 3.30 p.m.

—Madam President, on the point of order: obviously Senator Faulkner and his team do not listen. I do not want to make an explanation; I do not want to add to an answer yesterday. The answer I gave was fine as far as I was concerned, but someone I mentioned took umbrage at being associated with the Labor Party.

speech.para: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw, you are out of order on several grounds.

—Someone I mentioned took umbrage at being associated with the Labor Party, and I can well understand that. What I sought to do was to explain further what I said yesterday and to withdraw that, if that were the case. But if the Labor Party do not want me to do it, then I am happy to sit down.
—Senator, if you are not adding to an answer, you would need leave to make a statement.
—Madam President, I do not agree with your ruling but I accept it, and I will seek leave to make a personal statement.
—Is leave granted for Senator Ian Macdonald to make a brief statement?

interjection.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, in answering a question from Senator Mackay, in which she quoted a publication called Inside Canberra , I responded to some interjections by questioning whether Inside Canberra was a Labor Party publication and whether it was written by a fellow traveller. I indicated that I had not read the publication.

speech.para: I subsequently received a letter from Mr Rob Chalmers, the editor of Inside Canberra, who took exception to my comments as recorded in Hansard. A review of the video will show that the statement was not one of fact but was a question asked. Mr Chalmers has indicated that he considered my comment to be extremely damaging to his reputation as an independent political journalist, and therefore to his business, and he sought an immediate retraction and apology from me.

If anything I said suggested that Inside Canberra was a Labor Party publication or was written by a fellow traveller, then I do withdraw that imputation and apologise for it. I can well understand why any serious business person would not want to be associated with the Labor Party in any way whatsoever. My inquiry, in response to interjections, was certainly not intended to defame Mr Chalmers or to sully his reputation. I simply indicated that I had never heard of Inside Canberra before and I had never read it, and I had certainly not seen the article in question.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ray has kindly offered to provide me with a copy of the next newsletter, and I thank him for that. Obviously this is a newsletter that is well read by the Labor Party. I have had my staff find a copy of the edition in question, and I did look at it this morning. The way some of the comments are written, I can understand why people would suggest that the line followed in the newsletter is similar to the Labor Party line, but that does not excuse my saying it is a Labor Party newspaper. If I have offended Mr Chalmers, I do apologise. Certainly no harm was intended to him.
—A statement of that nature did need leave, which was granted.
—Madam President, I seek leave to make a very short statement.
—Is leave granted?

interjection.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —On Thursday, 24 June, during the committee stage of debate on the ANTS package, I stated correctly that bread or buns with sweet filling or coating would be subject to GST. That is on page 6048 of the transcript. I also noted correctly that bagels with blueberries as an ingredient would be GST free. It has come to my attention that Hansard subsequently records me as saying, `If it has a sweet filling or coating it is going to be GST free.' As I had previously stated to the Senate, breads or buns with a sweet filling or coating will be subject to GST.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked today by Senator Schacht, relating to the goods and services tax and the sale of wine.

I note that we have wasted 15 minutes on an extraordinary performance by Senator Ian Macdonald. I have moved this motion to take note because what Senator Kemp has said here today, and also what the Treasurer said last week, is a grave problem for the wine industry in Australia. I come from a state, South Australia, that contains the majority of the wine industry. This is a major problem for South Australia and the future of our wine industry. The introduction of the WET, the wine equalisation tax, will—despite what the Treasurer said last week in the parliament and despite the fact that Senator Kemp had no idea today about the details of it—increase taxation on the wine industry in South Australia and the rest of Australia.

The figures given by the Winemakers Federation have apparently not been disputed by the Treasurer or the government. The federation believes that the additional tax on the industry will total $147 million and will have a significant impact on jobs in regional Australia in particular. As South Australian senators would know, in the last decade one of the best developments for South Australia's future prosperity has been the growth of the wine industry. An area such as the Riverland had, 10 years ago, an unemployment rate of about 15 to 17 per cent. I understand that that unemployment rate is now down to six or seven per cent.

Most people suggest the reason for that is the general growth of the value-added horticultural industry and, in particular, the wine industry in that area. The same goes for the Clare Valley, Maclaren Vale, the Barossa Valley, Coonawarra and several other new areas that are now growing grapes in South Australia—as they are all around Australia. This is a success story that should be trumpeted from the rooftops of this building and elsewhere, about what a success it is and how the industry, through its own efforts, has grown. But what do we have? The only effort this government makes is to sneak through an increase in taxation that is worth nearly $150 million, under the guise of the wine equalisation tax.
When the new tax package was released, the government said:

Wine, and beverages consisting primarily of wine, will become subject to a Wine Equalisation Tax to replace the difference between the current 41 per cent wholesale sales tax and the proposed GST. The Wine Equalisation Tax will be levied at such a rate that the price of a four-litre cask of wine need only increase by the estimated general price increase associated with indirect tax reform; ie 1.9 per cent. The concessional tax treatment of cask wine will therefore be preserved.

No details were given further than that, and it was not until the wine industry belled the cat on the Treasurer that the Treasurer got up and said, `Oh no; this has all been fixed, as far as wine sales at the door are concerned: I have reached agreement with the Treasurer of South Australia.' Well, the Treasurer of South Australia, Mr Lucas, only two hours later in the parliament of South Australia said that South Australia had not reached any agreement. He refuted it completely.

We have now no guarantee that the rebate for the introduction of the WET will be administered and will be allowed for the individual wine growers and vignerons in Australia. Until we know what the answer is, this is going to do irreparable damage to the Australian wine industry, and not only to it but to the tourist industry. I find it astonishing that this government gets up and says all the time that it is about creating jobs and wealth and about getting off the back of industry but that, in this case, through a shambles of a chaotic approach to the management of the introduction of the new tax, it has—either through conspiracy or through not knowing what it is doing—actually harmed the wine industry, particularly the small wine growers and small wineries.

We do not have any commitment yet from the states that they will administer the rebate scheme of up to $300,000. All we know is that there will be an increase in taxation of $147 million per year on the wine industry in Australia, an industry that is just reaching $1 billion worth of export sales and is increasing its value to Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht certainly leads with his jaw. The question I would like to put is this: who is responsible for every cent of tax that is currently paid on wine in Australia? Who is responsible for every cent of tax that is currently paid by winemakers in Australia? The answer is the Labor Party.

speech.para: In 1983 there was no tax on wine at all; and yet the Labor Party in 1984 introduced a 10 per cent tax on it. It is all very well for Senator Schacht to leave the chamber, because in fact he was here for much of the time that the Labor Party chose to tax wine. In 1984 there was no tax on wine. The Labor Party introduced a 10 per cent rate. The wine industry said that it would break them and cause them to go out of business and that it would cost jobs.

The response from the Labor Party was to put another 10 per cent tax on wine in 1986 or 1987. Senator Sherry, you came here soon after the time that, not content to have a 10 per cent tax on wine, the Labor Party decided they would have a 20 per cent tax on wine. Of course, the winemakers complained and said that this would put them out of business, cost jobs and stop the fast-growing industry that was currently developing then throughout the 1980s.

But the Labor Party was not content with 20 per cent. In 1993 it tried to tax wine at 32 per cent. And what did we hear from the Labor Party? Not a word. We had the winemakers quite rightly saying this was an imposition on the industry and that it would cost jobs. Just because they were a successful industry, an industry that was growing in size and supplying exports, the Labor Party did not listen one iota until they were forced to back down in 1993, and so we got to the stage where, at two per cent per year, we had the tax on wine increasing until there was a wholesale sales tax of 26 per cent.

Senator Schacht should not come in here on behalf of the Labor Party and criticise anything that this government is doing in relation to the taxation of wine, because every cent that is currently paid is the responsibility of the Labor Party. The Labor Party felt at the time that the industry could bear that tax and those taxes that were imposed in 1984, and in 1986 or 1987—I cannot remember which year—and then again in 1993 onwards when it increased by two per cent per year.

We have taken a responsible attitude. Although there will be a slight increase in the rate of tax, the Labor Party never speaks about the compensation that is being offered through tax cuts to make the increase in wine more affordable to those people in the community who spend more of their disposable income on wine. If you are talking about premium wines, it is those at the high end of the income earning scale, those who will get the largest tax cuts, who will benefit the most, and wine will still be affordable.

The Labor Party's argument has holes in it from start to finish. They were never worried about putting tax on wine. The Labor Party thought that the wine industry was a milch cow which they could tax any time they liked. Whenever they wanted to increase taxes, they said, `Tax the wine industry.' Is it any wonder that we are very sceptical when people like Senator Schacht come in here—and I have heard Senator Sherry speak about it at length during the debate—talking about this terrible imposition that is being put on the wine industry, when in fact the Labor Party itself was responsible for every cent of tax that is currently being paid by the wine industry? I am sure the wine industry is aware of that. It is understandable that, at every stage of the proceedings, they are going to do everything they can to try to minimise the amount of tax they are paying into federal revenue.

We have had hearings and spent more time in consultation over this particular issue than probably any other aspect of the tax package. When it came to having submissions put before us, probably those in the wine industry have been longest and loudest in their representations to this government. It is a healthy industry. I represent the state of South Australia which produces 50 per cent of Australia's wine. The type of taxation that is on wine—the ad valorem taxation and the imposition of a WET tax—was supported by the Winemakers Federation of Australia, which represents all of the major producers and over some 400 small wineries throughout Australia.

The Winemakers Federation supports the framework of proposals that we put before the parliament in the new tax system. It is very cheap of the Labor Party to criticise any changes to the taxation on wine when in fact, as I said earlier, they were responsible for every cent that is being paid at present. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Labor Party makes no apologies for its wholesale sales tax on wine. It was the Liberal Party and Mr Costello, the Treasurer, who went to the last election saying that the Liberal Party was going to get rid of the wholesale sales tax and replace it with a GST. What did they do with the wine industry? They said that they would not just get rid of the wholesale sales tax and introduce a GST, but they would also introduce a big new tax on the wine industry, in addition to the GST, and that is the tax we are talking about—the WET tax. The impression was given by Treasurer Costello that the new tax and the GST on the wine industry would be revenue neutral.

speech.para: The representative of the Winemakers Federation, Mr Sutton—I do not consider him any great friend of the Labor Party—has said that the new wine equalisation tax and the GST will increase the tax take from the wine industry by $147 million a year or 12 per cent. He said:
The government—
that is, the Liberal government—
is pushing us now into the rarefied position of being the most highly taxed wine growing country in the world.

So the criticisms that the Liberal Party makes of our wholesale sales tax sound very hollow in respect of the way they have applied the GST and the new WET tax by slugging an extra $150 million from the wine industry in Australia.

The wine industry is now exporting $800 million in value. It is a very significant employer and value adder, particularly in rural and regional Australia, and particularly in areas like South Australia, Western Australia and my own home state of Tasmania which 20 years ago had no wine industry at all. The small wineries have been growing very rapidly and are significant employers in rural and regional areas. Another $147 million in tax on the wine industry, and the way in which the tax applies, will hit small wineries hardest.

I am not the only one who is concerned. Senator Ferguson spoke on behalf of the Liberal Party but his colleague Senator Winston Crane, who is chair of the government's agricultural committee, said the wine tax policy `could be better and fairer'. He fired a letter off to the Treasurer, Mr Costello, who responded:
According to Treasury analysis, there is about an eight per cent in revenue collected under both the WET tax and the GST as compared to the collection under the current wholesale sales tax.

The Treasurer finally owned up in June this year to his own colleague Senator Crane that he had been misleading the Australian people and particularly misleading the Australian wine industry in his claims that they would not be seeking extra revenue from the GST and the new wine tax.

But it gets worse. We then had this shoddy little deal between the Democrats and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, with respect to the wine industry. The Treasurer has assured the wine industry, and misled them, by claiming that small wineries will be able to keep a rebate on cellar door and mail order sales for winery sales up to $300,000. He said:
. . . ensure that the states will keep arrangements providing for rebates on cellar door and mail order sales for wineries up to $300,000.
The Treasurer went on:
. . . the states should be in a position to continue those rebate schemes. Indeed, I understand that South Australia has already indicated it will . . .
One hour later, his Liberal colleague, the state treasurer of South Australia said, when asked about this:
No, it's not true. We have not been consulted, so at this stage we cannot agree to anything.
We have had the Treasurer of this country mislead the wine industry, not once but twice, and those dills, the Australian Democrats, fell for it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME BILL 1999

cognateinfo.title: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE AMENDMENT (DIESEL FUEL REBATE SCHEME) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —When debate on the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 was interrupted, I was speaking on the rural elements of the bill and drawing attention to the very dirty exhaust signatures of a lot of diesel engines in Australia. I said that this was a consequence of poor or no maintenance at all which resulted in dirty injectors or badly worn engines. I was leading up to making the point that it is wrong that we have not had exhaust emission legislation covering diesel engines in Australia up to the present time.

speech.para: The great advantage of this bill is that it will provide some standards for the community. For nearly 20 years, under the Australian design rules, petrol engines have been forced to meet tighter emission controls. They are not the tightest in the world today, but they are progressively getting tighter. There has certainly been a great community benefit from that, but there has also been a cost. It has been unfair that purchasers of vehicles with petrol engines have had to pay thousands of dollars towards the cost of both research and development and the implementation of emission control devices to their engines while diesel operators have not had any similar requirement placed upon them.

This bill introduces mandatory emission requirements starting in 2002, I think, with these being progressively implemented in subsequent years to different sizes of engines. One of the points that the previous speaker, Senator Cook, made in this debate was that these requirements were not to the Californian standard. I spoke earlier about how, if you drive around California—particularly Los Angeles—you will not see any visible exhaust signature from diesel engines, irrespective of the size of the engine, the load on the vehicle, the speed at which it is travelling and so on.

I want to answer Senator Cook's point that we should have introduced Californian standards. The first point to be made is that Australia is moving, wherever possible, towards international standards. With the greatest respect for California, their emission standards are not accepted by the international community. The world is not harmonising with California; it is harmonising with United Nations standards. Those standards are reflected in the current European Union standards, which are the ones that this bill nominates. Those European standards are consistent with best international practice and they will deliver major improvements in emission control, particularly from an environmental point of view. It is also to be borne in mind that, by meeting these stricter standards, the future of road transport or diesel transport is enhanced because, quite simply, in 20 years time we would not be able to operate with the lack of controls that we have at present. Unless the industry moves to a more effective control of emissions, community pressure would be such that they would be banned.

The standards mandated in the years ahead will give us very significant improvements. From a manufacturing point of view, it should be pointed out that modern engines are far more reliable in being able to maintain an emission control standard than those in the past, mainly because the fuel control systems in them cannot be readily altered from manufacturer specifications by mechanics or drivers.

My concern with the legislation is not along the lines of Senator Cook's concern that it does not conform to Californian specifications, but rather with the slowness with which change will take place. By definition, diesel engines last much longer than petrol engines and, since these standards will apply from 2002 onwards, it will only be a very slow, incremental improvement in emission control standards across the whole of the fleet as new vehicles join it. At a rough guess, it may be 10 or 15 years before we see any appreciable reduction in diesel emissions because of the longevity of diesel transport and the high cost of such transport. The dilution factor from new vehicles will not be apparent for quite a while.

My plea is that the government should legislate in the near term for some emission control standards for diesel engines. Obviously, they will have to be at a lower emission control standard than that mandated for in the years ahead because those standards will require some design modification to the engine itself. But even if we tighten up on the standard of maintenance by requiring a clear exhaust signature with no black smoke coming out, I think the community will benefit enormously. I commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —These are some of the most important pieces of legislation against both social justice principles and the environmental good of this country that I have seen in my time in the Senate. What is quite extraordinary about this legislation is that, following the support by all seven Democrats of the disastrous environmental legislation of last week, all seven Democrats are now supporting a massive redistribution of wealth and a massive impost on the environment. This legislation gives back the diesel fuel rebate to principally mining, logging and transport corporations.

speech.para: Let me make it clear from the outset that the major beneficiaries of this Democrat-government legislation will be the mining corporations of this country. While the Democrats' GST package will put a GST impost on hot pies, hot chooks and chicken pieces, and a whole range of things that are important to average Australians, it will lift the diesel fuel taxes off the big mining, logging and transport corporations. This involves a massive redistribution of wealth in this country. The Democrats, through the GST package, tax Australians right across the board, but they give the multi-billion dollar breaks, through this legislation, to the big end of town, in particular the big mining corporations.

It is no wonder that we had the comments coming out of the meeting that the Democrats had with the bankers, the day before they began negotiations on the GST legislation, that business was feeling more comfortable with the Democrats and, reciprocally, the Democrats could look to getting more support. By this I mean tangible donations support. They will not be getting it from small business; they will not be getting it from low income earners; they will not be getting it from people who are struggling to make ends meet. But the expectation is there, at least from some of the senior Democrats, that they will be getting it from the mining corporations.

The cost to the community will be wider than that, because we will have more polluted cities and there will be a boost to the enormous global problem of warming of the planet as carbon dioxide and other global warming gases are increasingly put into our atmosphere. Australia is one of the worst offenders, per head of population, of any community around the world. Just last night the minister who claims to represent the environment, Senator Hill, finally admitted that this package will see greenhouse gas emissions increase by 2.2 per cent—that was on the Four Corners program—compared with the target for Kyoto, which was to restrict the limit to eight per cent. We are only talking about transport in this country. We are not talking about the increasing destruction of forests, which leads to global warming gases being released, and we are not talking about things such as three new coal-fired power stations on the slate for Queensland. In a bid to ameliorate this bill's impact, I foreshadow a second reading amendment, as distributed, which reads:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"further consideration of the bill be an order of the day for the first sitting day after the conditions specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) have been met:

(a) determinations to raise motor vehicle emission standards, at least to the levels specified in subclauses 2(2) and 2(4) of the bill, have been made under section 7 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 ; and
(b) amounts listed in the third column of the table in clause 5 of the bill, for the programs specified in that table, have been appropriated".

What that all means is that the passage of the bill be delayed at least until the harder, more environmentally sound, emission standards that are mooted in the bill are in place. What the bill says is that those standards should be in place before the bill has effect. Let us hold off the debate until those emission standards are in place.

I want to deal with emission standards because I am sure Senator Lees, who will follow me in this debate, is going to claim big breakthroughs for the Democrats. But the Democrats were dudded. The evidence has surfaced since they did the deal with the government, for those who have not been watching this closely, that the emission standards involved in this legislation were on their way. These emission standards do not put Australia to the forefront of the world: they are a catch-up. They mean that there will be improved emission control on vehicles being sold on the market in Australia which catches up with Europe and the United States. Australia has been 10 years behind. Two years ago, before the Kyoto talks in Japan, the Prime Minister made a commitment to do just that.

All the Democrats have is a corroboration of a commitment made to this nation two years ago by the Prime Minister. But, in return, the Democrats have sold out comprehensively on their own commitments to the environment. At the last election, Senator Lees and her six fellow Democrat senators, and the party, promised to exclude petrol and diesel products from the GST and to retain the current excises. So there was going to be no tax cut for business vehicles via the GST rebate. They have dropped that promise and it is very important that we look at the result.

Because the Democrats have broken that promise, they are giving the big end of town a petrol and diesel price cut of 7c a litre in effect. That is what the GST rebate will mean. The total will be $2.2 billion per annum going to business, corporate and stock exchange interests around this country. Average Australians will not get this rebate. You can drive your car down to the shop and back but you will not have the Democrat cheque in the mail when you get home rebating the GST on fuel. But if you are a business, you get the GST rebated. The total rebate will be $2.2 billion.

talk.start.para: —What is the system now? What do you think they can do now?

—Senator Lees, there is not a GST on this at the moment. You brought in the GST and you brought in the refund for big business. And it is not small pickles. Senator Lees knows that it is $2.2 billion a year. Think what that could do for schools. Think what that could have done for books if, instead of giving the money to these big corporations, the GST had been taken off books, as Senator Lees promised.

speech.para: The Democrats went on to promise to oppose the extension of the 100 per cent rebate of diesel fuel beyond agriculture. That is, they were going to cap the current diesel fuel rebate for mining, logging, et cetera, and redistribute it equally across all other uses. That would have effectively meant an increase in fuel costs for the big mining and logging corporations. That promise is broken in this legislation. Instead they will abolish fuel taxes for mining. They keep logging the same and cut the costs of transport fuel for both by 23c a litre. No wonder the mining lobby is rubbing its hands with glee at this Democrat gift.

As Senator Parer was able to tell us all just last year, in this package the coalition is going to give—and now read the Democrats as well—Australia's mining industries more than $2 billion a year.
