subdebate.1.para: Messages received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that the House has made the requested amendments in the bills.
Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the bills be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry I am out of breath, but my understanding was that this message was going to be received by the chamber at 10 p.m, and it is a few minutes before the hour.

speech.para: I wish to oppose the motion that the bills be read a third time. On the voting pattern we have seen over the last week, this motion is likely to succeed. In opposing it, I take the opportunity to speak on the third reading to mark the unhappiness the opposition feel about the passage of this legislation. The Prime Minister has declared today, Tuesday, 29 June, as a historic day. It is not historic for the reasons that he has declared; it is a day of shame for Australia, and it is a day on which we have a sad and a bad outcome for our economy. It is the day on which the GST has landed in Australia. If this motion is carried, as I suspect it will be, we will have a GST. It is not a triumph, and it is not a tax for a new millennium. It is not a new tax at all; it is an old tax, and it is a tax for an old millennium. At the very time when many in Europe are calling for the rolling back of this tax, Australia, at the beginning of the new century, is beginning to adopt one.

I want to acknowledge a number of things that have happened on the road to this date, which began at least eight months ago in terms of this chamber and over a year and a half ago in terms of the journey of the GST. The GST started out as an announcement by the Prime Minister that we were going to engage in a great tax adventure. It has been a great tax misadventure. About eight months ago we started to consider a Senate inquiry. I have to say the Senate inquiry has served this chamber well and has revealed the shameful deceit that the government entered into when it published the ANTS package prior to the election, seeking a mandate for the GST.

The Senate inquiry revealed a number of things—too many for me to itemise now. But what it showed clearly was that, for the first time, many of the propositions that the government had advanced unchallenged to the Australian community were flawed or were wrong and that many of the assumptions that the Liberal-National coalition had based its views on had not been properly modelled. When the work was done, flaws in those assumptions became obvious. It became clear that the 1.9 per cent inflation effect was not the inflation effect at all. It was a qualified inflation effect. It was an inflation effect for the second year, not the first year, and it was qualified by the considering out of the equation household purchases and cigarette smoking. So it was an inflation effect that did not reflect the true purchasing pattern of the Australian community.

We learnt as well that the so-called export benefits of this legislation were not as the government claimed, because in evidence to the inquiry Treasury contended that the exchange rate will of course correct to offset those alleged benefits and that, for many of our industries most dependent on the exchange rate—industries where international supply is overhanging demand, particularly the minerals industry and the agriculture industry—an upward movement in the exchange rate will damage their prospects even further. It is therefore a clear assertion that the government has misled the Australian community about the export effects—that, in fact, the export effects are not there.

We learnt that the so-called benefits that older Australians, particularly pensioners, would receive from the government would erode with time and that they were exposed. We learnt as well that there were a group of Australians who were not associated with the tax system—those in the welfare system—in the sense that the government alleged and that they would be affected. We learnt as well that the distribution of the tax cuts favoured the wealthy and hurt the poor. And we learnt a range of other things which showed the fundamental inequity of the tax system.

I think that the Senate has to acknowledge the role played by that inquiry. The role in that inquiry played by Labor was to expose the hypocrisy of the government's position and to highlight the truth of the matter. We were concerned to bring out the facts and have a genuine public scrutiny of this legislation—to challenge the smug assertions that were delivered to the Australian community laced with electoral hyperbole to persuade people that this tax system should be embraced. It played a significant role.

I want to acknowledge as well the role played by Senator Harradine who, as it was said, uncharacteristically—but with great conscientiousness on this occasion—attended most, if not all, of the hearings and participated as a member of that committee. His speech several Fridays ago in which he said that he could not support this legislation—in his words, `I cannot'—was one of the most significant speeches made in my period in this Senate and a speech, as I said at the time, of great moral courage. Senator Harradine had been a senator who, I think it is fair to say, had examined every avenue in which you could compensate fairly for this GST. He came to the fundamental conclusion that you cannot compensate for it, and therefore the conclusion that a moral person must make when confronted with the facts: you cannot support it because it is unfair to Australians who are unable to fend for themselves.

I want to acknowledge—but not in the same way—the role played by the Australian Democrats. I believe, and I have said in this debate, that they repudiated elements that were non-negotiable in their electoral platform by engaging in accepting an outcome and voting for it, as they have done over the last several weeks. That is a matter for their conscience. It is not a matter for Labor's conscience, and it is not a situation in which I revel that the Australian Democrats have exposed themselves to allegations of insincerity that must obviously flow. But I note for the record that they have had a challenge to their leadership, that their ranks are divided and that there is widespread disquiet in their electoral community about their actions and, as a co-author with the government of this legislation, they will bear the electoral consequences of that. They will argue that they have improved the package, and there will be some truth to that argument. The trouble is that they have not improved it sufficiently and the basic injustices of this package remain. They remain slightly dented, but they remain as strong injustices that will be encoded into the Australian taxation system permanently.

The truth about a GST is that the amount of the tax always rises and the compensation to offset the damage done to low and middle income earners always falls. They are the two ironclad truths of a GST wherever it has been implemented in the world, and there is nothing in this package to say that the Australian experience will be different. Therefore, it is for those who propose this tax and for those who support it and enable its passage to answer eventually as to why it is that they want to visit on Australia a tax of this nature.

It will be said that Labor supported the wholesale sales tax and we supported a system that involves the wholesale sales tax. That is true. Had we had the opportunity following the election, we would have of course modified the Australian tax system and made it better.

talk.start.para: —You only had 13 years.

—I take the interjection. We were and, as a matter of historic record, are a party of significant tax reform. Let me start at the beginning. In 1983 we inherited a tax system which many of the economic commentators said was a shambles and in which the payment of tax was a voluntary commitment for those wealthy enough to do so. We wiped out the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes that we inherited from this government. We introduced a national tax summit in 1985. We made major reforms to the tax system, and we are committed to continuing to do so. Had we been elected, we would have continued to do that. But we were not elected, so we were not able to continue.

speech.para: We stand for tax reform without a GST and we stand for it solidly. During our period in office, we lowered the top marginal rate that we inherited from the Fraser government. The Fraser government's view of a reasonable tax system—a government in which the now leader of the coalition government was the Treasurer—was one in which the top marginal rate was 60 per cent. I say to the government: if you want to make the jibe about us, you will have to answer the jibe about you.

The GST is nothing more than an alternative means of collecting tax. It is not a panacea for the Australian economy, as has been claimed by the government and now the Australian Democrats. The GST will not create a single job. The GST will not add to economic growth. The GST will not make our exports more competitive. The GST will add to inflation over and above the government's projections. The GST will see hot chooks taxed but cold chooks untaxed. This is claimed to be an example of our new, modern, efficient and competitive tax system—a system where a tax liability is now determined on the basis of a thermometer test. This is our new, modern tax system for a new century, and it is derisory.

The GST will force charities to cut back services to the poor as they divert resources to becoming tax collectors for Lees, Howard and Costello. The GST will be a nightmare on main street for 1.6 million Australian businesses as they struggle to comply with the GST disaster. Any stimulus from the tax package will come from the $12 billion worth of tax cuts, not from the GST. The GST taxes the necessities of life, in many cases for the first time. The GST treats the cost of raising children as an expense to the community as opposed to an investment in this nation's future prosperity. The tax cuts awarded to bribe people into supporting this package are skewed towards the wealthy at the expense of the poor. It is obvious that, for the Democrats, it was more important in the end to do the deal than to stick by principle. There is a provision in that deal that rewards millionaire high-rollers in Australia, who will get a tax break by courtesy of their casinos, rather than compensating adequately—or providing protection by imposing no GST—pensioners, families, the unemployed, self-funded retirees and low income earners. This will be the yardstick by which the Democrats' commitment to the underprivileged will be measured—tax breaks for millionaire high-rollers but nothing else for the rest of the community.

The government will boast, probably tomorrow—it has already begun tonight—as to where there will be tax cuts for Australians. We challenge those views because we believe that not all of those tax cuts will be passed on in full at the time and that the savings will not, therefore, be pocketed by those who are the consumers; they will be diverted to those who are the profit takers. But while they are lauding what are supposedly the price reduc tions of some goods in the Australian community, we must remember that this is a tax on everything, and many services for the first time will be taxed. A family outing to the football or to the rugby will be taxed. Taking children to McDonald's will be taxed for the first time. School uniforms, shoes, books, bus fares, outings, camps, user fees and computer software will be taxed. Car maintenance will be taxed for the first time. For the first time, we will be paying a tax on our car insurance. Housing insurance will be taxed. There will be a tax on haircuts. Legal fees for divorces, wills and conveyancing—any legal fee—will be taxed. Accounting fees will be taxed, and when people seek the assistance of an accountant for their tax returns, that will be taxed. Electrical and plumbing work, carpentry and housing in general will be taxed. Funerals will be taxed. Having your lawn mowed and having your house painted will be taxed. Taking the wife and kids on a holiday will be taxed. Books, shamefully, will be taxed. Public transport will be taxed. The airfares of tourists who come to Australia will not be taxed but the airfares of domestic tourists will be taxed.

The list of what will be taxed for the first time is long. The so-called compensation for this tax will not be adequate to meet the needs over time. At the end of the day, the inescapable arithmetical truth about this tax is that it is a flat tax payable by everyone, irrespective of their income. The government has offered tax bribes as a momentary inducement for people to accept it, but they are bribes that will erode over time and leave the nation worse off. This is not a tax for a new millennium; this is a shameful day in the history of Australian taxation. This is not reform. This is tax deform. We will oppose the third reading of this legislation.

—I would like to speak to the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 , and the reason is that it was one of those bills that was put forward as a non-controversial bill, and the Greens (WA) certainly do not believe it is a non-controversial bill. I think it will be one of those bills where perhaps the government might say to us, `Everybody thinks it is okay except for you,' and it might be prophetic for us to say that there are issues which the vast majority of people in the community of Australia would feel very concerned about. I know that—

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, colleagues! Senator Margetts deserves a hearing.

—Thank you. You will be pleased to know that I will not be speaking for my full time, but I would like to put some issues on the table. Because of the guillotine, the time for debate of this bill is small. There are huge and significant policy changes in this bill relating to changing Australia to a regional financial centre, and we have less than one hour to put the issues on the record. I, of course, will not take all that time, but I would like to think that there will be other people who will be participating in this debate. I would like to think that this bill will not go through without a peep from other parties in this chamber.

speech.para: Especially in the context of the last week we have gone through, with no less than three guillotines in the last sitting days, as a part of Australia as a regional finance centre this bill dramatically expands the number of entities that can be considered offshore banking units, OBUs, and the range of concessions that they receive. I do not always listen to talkback radio in any detail but, listening to the community within Australia, I do not think they would necessarily be putting their hand up to give further tax concessions to banks and those involved in speculative transactions, the big players of the market generally, while they are watching concessions from other industries and, in fact, watching where there is no industry policy in other industries.

The explanatory memorandum says in respect of schedule 1 that offshore banking unit concessions will be expanded to extend the range of entities eligible to register as offshore banking units, provide a tax exemption for income and capital gains of overseas charitable institutions managed by an OBU—which is interesting because we have just put more tax on charitable institutions and more problems associated with that as a result of the GST. It will extend the range of eligible OBU activities to include custodial services, trading in Australian dollars where the other party in the transaction is an offshore person, trading in gold bullion with offshore persons in any currency, trading in gold bullion with any person other than in Australian dollars, trading in base metals and palladium bullion with offshore persons in any currency, other trading activities apart from currency trading in Australian dollars with offshore persons, eligible contract activities in Australian dollars with offshore persons, and hedging in Australian dollars with related offshore persons.
This relates to the transfer of money and often can be associated with speculative trading. The thing which is not necessarily—
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, colleagues! Senator Bishop, I would like to caution a gentle hush.

—Thank you. This is not necessarily associated with the mass creation of jobs. There are people involved with consultancies, but in fact we are talking about the transfers of large amounts of money—not necessarily commensurate with the number of jobs that are provided. The explanatory memorandum says that it removes `the current anti-avoidance measure which prevents Australia being used as a conduit to channel loans to other countries'. That means Australia obviously will be used more to channel loans as a conduit to other countries. Is this what we want? I will return to this later.

speech.para: It reduces the capital gains tax liability where non-residents dispose of interests in offshore banking unit investment trusts and provides a foreign tax credit for foreign tax paid by Australian resident offshore banking units, regardless of whether a double taxation agreement applies—so we could be losing out on revenue. It removes the requirement that offshore banking units maintain separate nostro and vostro accounts for OBU transactions, and reduces the rate of offshore banking unit withholding penalty tax for breaches of the IWT concession from 300 per cent to 75 per cent.

Without necessarily going into the full details of that, I would like to indicate that these concessions may well be involved in significant financial subsidy for some of these transactions. Some of these extensions of concessions might be reasonable and may be justifiable, but there are two major points we should make.

The government is putting through significant concessions for offshore banking units—in effect, corporate welfare—while so many groups in the community and industry groups are fighting tooth and nail to get the most measly concessions and have obviously lost that in relation to the GST package. For instance, charities are having to pay GST and there are major compliance costs. In fact, charities are losing some of the tax advantages in relation to FBT and reporting requirements. Of course, Senator Kemp will get up and say, `No, charities are exempt in a lot of aspects,' but we know there will be significant compliance costs and that there are other areas where they will not be exempt.

Concerning education and health institutions and practitioners, we know the tax treatment is making it more expensive and more difficult to access choice in respect of education and health institutions. In addition, the GST discriminates between different health practitioners. Another example is local government where many essential community services will be subject to GST and local governments will have a compliance nightmare in working out what is in and what is out.

The policy we are dealing with tonight makes assumptions that, if Australia is the next Hong Kong or Singapore, we will gain a great many benefits. This is similar to the blind faith that free trade will bring all of us economic growth, prosperity and happiness—I just saw another pink flier. There was basically no proper cost benefit impact analysis when we signed up to GATT and the World Trade Organisation.

This is a similar situation. When we look at the benefits and the detriment of handing out concessions to business, we have to look at the opportunity costs: that is, what are we losing in doing this? Would it not be better to be encouraging other industries such as tourism, which got the bad end of the GST deal, despite it being an industry that can improve our current account and foreign debt deficit by improving our balance of trade? It also employs a huge number of people and will be damaged considerably by the introduction of the ANTS package.

A note from Minister Hockey's office indicates that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 will help turn the tide of our current account and foreign debt deficits by improving our balance of trade, allowing for low interest rates. I would say that that is very hopeful. He says, `Similarly, the interest withholding tax initiative is designed to develop a corporate bond market that essentially does not really exist in Australia.' I would like to see what the benefits of that would be. He says, `Promotion of the benefits for Australia, instead of Singapore or Hong Kong, is to be undertaken by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation.' There is nothing to say what the assumed benefits are, except that, if we get investment and if we pay people a concession, somehow or other the benefits will flow—the trickle down effect.

To get back to the other industries that have been badly affected in the last few days, tourism lobby groups have predicted huge impacts on the tourist industry from the introduction of the GST, including the loss of around 59,000 full- and part-time jobs. I would like to know whether or not we are looking at anything like that number of jobs, as associated with this handout to international corporate finance.

The huge impact on employment in the tourist industry was also backed up by modelling done by Professor Dixon for the Senate committee. While the estimates were not quite as large, it was estimated in the central simulation that there would be job losses to the order of 4.3 per cent or around 19,880 jobs. It is an immense contrast and, like so many other bills that have been shoved through the Senate during this sitting period, deserves significantly more consideration.

We would have many concerns about aspects of this bill and the very concept of making Australia a conduit for financial transactions without having done proper studies. We will not be moving amendments in light of the time for preparation and acknowledging the numbers on the floor tonight. But this is a major policy change. I am sure, given the kinds of decisions that have been made over the last few days, that the community would be worried not only that the government was going along with this but that the opposition thought that this was a whizzbang idea as well. In the future, I think this might jump up and bite both the government and the opposition in relation to its actual impacts.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to incorporate my speech.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Very briefly, I want to say that I am glad for the financial sector, as well as for Mr Joe Hockey, that this Bill will be passing the Senate today.

As a roving ambassador for the financial sector, Mr Hockey will now have something meaningful and positive to say to the international community about recent Government initiatives to make Australia a key financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region.
Contrary to previous claims by the Government, the opposition has little to do in delaying this Bill. The fact that it is being considered today as non-controversial proves this point.
Rather, better management by the Government might have seen this Bill considered and passed by the Senate much sooner.
The proposals to improve the Offshore Banking Unit and Interest Withholding Tax regimes will help promote Australia as a financial centre.

In particular, the extension of the OBU concessional rate to the activities of funds managers and life insurance companies, and to activities such as hedging and trading of Australian dollar denominated instruments with other offshore persons are welcomed.

The broadening of exemptions to IWT available under Section 128 is also a positive move. As part of the revised exemptions companies will be able to issue debentures and can make interest payments in either Australia or offshore, thus allowing companies to offer bearer debentures simultaneously to investors in Australia and overseas.
No doubt, industry will express disappointment that the IWT will remain applicable on Government bonds.

I recall that Mr Hockey was open to reconsidering this arrangement, but was very quickly shot-down by the Treasurer. That was fair enough, I guess, due to the potentially significant loss in revenue if sovereign bonds were exempted. Treasury was quoted in the press as estimating a figure "north of $100 million".
The so-called thin capitalisation measure may prove to be a precursor to further thin capitalisation recommendations from the Ralph Business Tax Review.

The proposal on thin capitalisation will allow an Australian subsidiary of a foreign bank to raise 128F IWT exempt funds and on-lend those funds to the branch of the foreign bank operating in Australia without reducing the subsidiary's ability to claim tax deductions for interest paid on loans from foreign related parties.
It is disappointing that the gains from these initiatives are to be clawed back by the input taxing under the GST of financial services from 1 July 2000.
I am sure that Mr Hockey will not be talking about the effects of the GST on the financial sector when he makes his roadshow overseas.
He will not be mentioning that the GST input taxing of financial services would lead to complexity and distortions.
In addition, I expect that he will not be mentioning the fact that certain taxes that the GST is supposed to have eliminated will remain beyond 2000.
The financial institutions duty on deposits will remain until 2002 and the bank account debits tax on withdrawals will not be abolished until 2005.
There are also measures to counter tax avoidance activities with regard to franking credits and inter-corporate dividend rebate. These measures are supported by the Labor Party.
The Labor Party also supports the amendment to the retrospective element of the proposal relating to distributions to beneficiaries and partners that are equivalent to interests.

talk.start.para: —I would like to respond to the comments made in this debate. One of the major measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 is aimed at making Australia a more attractive regional financial centre and honours the Prime Minister's commitment in his `Investing for Growth' statement made in December 1997. The franking credit trading measures, which complement other legislation the government has passed in the last year, will protect the revenue base. The bill also sets out the choice of depreciation methods for entities that become taxable and introduces an anti-avoidance rule for commercial debt forgiveness.

speech.para: I foreshadow that I will be moving some amendments to the franking credit trading measures on behalf of the government. The measures were circulated some time ago. I commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —They were circulated about five minutes ago.
—I have received advice that they were tabled last week.
—For the Senate's information, I have been advised that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 amendments just mentioned by the minister were tabled on 22 June at 12.15 p.m.
—I was given them by the attendant in the Senate only five minutes ago.
—I am advised that they were circulated, Senator Margetts.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the government, I will be moving amendments to the franking credit trading measures in schedules 4 and 7 of the bill. I seek leave to move the amendments together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 4, item 8, page 90 (line 33) to page 91 (line 9), omit subsection (10), substitute:

para.inline: Deltas of positions to be taken not to have changed in certain circumstances

speech.para: (a) a taxpayer acquires shares or interests in shares; and
(b) on the day of the acquisition, or on a later day, the taxpayer enters into or has positions in relation to any of the shares or interests;
then, so long as the taxpayer continues to hold the shares or interests, continues to have those positions and does not enter into any further positions in relation to the shares or interests:
(c) in calculating the delta of a position held by the taxpayer in relation to the shares or interests:
(i) for the purposes of this Division other than paragraphs 106APHO(1)(b) and 160APHP(1)(b); or

(ii) for the purposes of either of those paragraphs in its application to a related payment under an arrangement entered into before the commencement of this subsection, other than an arrangement that has been varied, renewed or replaced after that commencement;
those positions are taken to continue to have the deltas that they had on the later of the following days:
(iii) the day on which the shares or interests were acquired;
(iv) a day on which any of the positions was entered into; or

(d) in calculating the delta of a position held by the taxpayer in relation to the shares or interests for the purposes of paragraph 160APHO(1)(b) or 160APHP(1)(b) in its application to a related payment under an arrangement:
(i) entered into after the commencement of this subsection (including an arrangement that renewed or replaced an arrangement entered into before that commencement); or
(ii) entered into before that commencement that was varied after that commencement;
those positions are taken to continue to have the deltas that they had on the latest of the following days:
(iii) the day on which the shares or interests were acquired by the taxpayer;
(iv) a day on which any of the positions that the taxpayer has in relation to the shares or interests was entered into;

(v) if the secondary qualification period in relation to the taxpayer in relation to the shares or interests is the second, or a subsequent, qualification period since the shares or interests were acquired by the taxpayer—the first day of the secondary qualification period.
(2) Schedule 4, item 25, page 124 (line 34) to page 125 (line 4), omit subitem (9), substitute:
(9) A reference in a provision inserted in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by this Schedule to a related payment in respect of a dividend or distribution:

(a) is a reference to a related payment under an arrangement entered into after 7.30 pm by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory on 13 May 1997, whether or not the shares or interests in shares in respect of which the dividend was paid or the distribution was made were acquired by the taxpayer before or after that time; but
(b) does not include a reference to a related payment made under a contract for the sale of derivatives known as Share Price Index Futures that was made before 2 July 1998.
(3) Schedule 7, item 2, page 185 (lines 23 to 26), omit subparagraph (c)(i), substitute:

(i) in respect of an interest in the trust or partnership that was created before the commencing time and either was acquired on or after 2 July 1998 or was created or acquired for a term that was extended at or after the commencing time; or
(ia) in respect of an interest in the trust or partnership that was created at or after the commencing time; or

Amendment 1 makes a correction to the rule for determining a taxpayer's position in relation to shares for purpose of the related payments rule to ensure that it gives an appropriate and consistent outcome. The related payments rule requires taxpayers who are under an obligation to make a related payment with respect to a dividend to hold shares at risk for at least 45 days to be eligible for franking credits. Amendment 1 will amend the new subsection 160APHJ(10) in item 8 of schedule 4 so that the positions held by a taxpayer will be recalculated for each dividend period. This change will take effect from the day the bill receives royal assent.

Amendment 2 will amend subitem 25(9) in schedule 4 so that the related payments rule will not apply to a related payment under an arrangement for the sale of the derivatives, known as share price index futures, entered into before 2 July 1998 when draft legislation for the measure was introduced into the parliament. Apart from this exception, the related payments rule will continue to apply to related payments in respect of a dividend or distribution under an arrangement entered into after 7.30 p.m. on 13 May 1997 when the measure was announced. This amendment addresses an issue raised by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee regarding the application of the related payments rule.

In amendment 3, the new section 45ZA in item 2 to schedule 7 will deny franking credit benefits to the intercorporate dividend rebate for distributions attributable to dividends to beneficiaries and partners that are equivalent to interest on a loan. Amendment 3 will amend a new paragraph 45ZA(l)(c) so that the changes to section 45Z will not apply to distributions attributable to an interest in a trust or partnership acquired before 2 July 1998 when the draft legislation for the measure was introduced into the parliament. New section 45ZA will apply to distributions attributable to interests in trusts or partnerships acquired on or after 2 July 1998 and to distributions attributable to interests in trusts or partnerships created or extended after 7.30 p.m. on 13 May 1997 when the measure was announced. The amendment gives effect to a recommendation of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. The changes made in amendments 1 to 3 will have a negligible effect on compliance costs.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1999:

question.para: With reference to the refugee situation on the border of Burma and Thailand:
(1) What assistance is provided to refugees and asylum seekers in Thailand by the Australian Embassy in Bangkok.
(2) What assistance is provided to refugees and asylum seekers in Burma by the Australian Embassy in Rangoon.

(3) (a) What is the Australian Government's official position in relation to Burmese refugees and asylum seekers at the Thai border; and (b) what does the embassy do in instances where a refugee or asylum seeker does not have the correct paper work, including identity papers, passports, etc., required for their processing as a refugee or asylum seeker.
(4) What is the process for the granting of a visa to a Burmese visitor, refugee or asylum seeker by the Australian Government in both Rangoon and Bangkok.
(5) Does the Government have a quota for Burmese refugees and asylum seekers.

(6) (a) What is the Government's position in relation to the granting of visas to members of the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC), previously the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC); and (b) has the Australian Government ever granted visas to members of SPDC or members of their families, or any members previously of the SLORC or their families; if so, to whom was a visa granted.
(7) Can details be provided of travel movements of members of SPDC and their families into and out of Australia over the past 5 years.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Refugees and asylum seekers in Thailand who apply for inclusion in Australia's Humanitarian Program have their application individually considered on its merits at the Australian Embassy in Bangkok. The Australian Embassy in Bangkok continually monitors the situation of displaced persons in the border camps.

(2) For the past several years the Australian Embassy in Rangoon has not been able to grant any visas under the Burmese in Burma Special Assistance Category (SAC) because in 1995 the Burmese authorities decided not to allow these visa holders to exit Burma. The Australian Embassy in Rangoon continually monitors the human rights situation in Burma.

(3) (a) UNHCR does not seek third country resettlement for persons in the border camps at this time. The Australian Government has accepted UNHCR's assessment of the situation. We are therefore not currently resettling people from border camps. (b) Verification of identity is an important step in granting a visa and allowing entry to Australia. In the case of Humanitarian Program applicants the Australian Embassy does all within its power to assist applicants, even if they do not have all their personal documentation.

(4) The process is the same at Australian visa offices throughout the world—receipt of application, verification of identity, consideration case by case against the regulatory requirements, grant of visa if all requirements are met.

(5) Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program is a planned program with global and regional allocations within a framework of a notional annual planning figure of 10,000 offshore visas. The priority regions are the former Yugoslavia, the Middle East and Africa. Bangkok has an allocation of 100 places for the Burmese in Thailand SAC in the 1998-99 program year.

(6) (a) If an applicant satisfies the Minister that all the relevant legislative criteria for a particular visa as set out in the Migration Act 1958 and Migration Regulations 1994 are met, then the applicant is granted a visa. The visa would, therefore, be refused if the applicant is assessed to be a risk to Australian national security, or if the applicant's presence in Australia would prejudice relations between Australia and a foreign country.

(b) All applicants to visit Australia are considered on a case by case basis. Individual movements are recorded by name, passport details, visa details and date on the Department's movement data base. It is therefore not possible to provide travel details into and out of Australia without specific names of individuals to check the movement data base against.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 May 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Australian Government's decision to back China against international resolutions condemning China's human rights record: what public record has been made of Australia's bilateral talks on human rights since 1997; if there is no public record, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I assume that the honourable Senator's question refers to a draft resolution on the human rights situation in China which was proposed by the United States at this year's meeting of the Commission on Human Rights (CHR). This resolution did not go to a vote as China successfully moved a "no action" motion. As an observer at CHR, Australia did not vote on the motion. Like the EU and most other Western States, Australia did not agree to co-sponsor the draft resolution because it had become apparent over a seven year period that the process of confrontation with China over such resolutions was counter-productive. The Government's assessment is that, over time, bilateral dialogue is the more effective means of achieving results.

The Joint Statement made at the conclusion of the first meeting of the Australia China human rights dialogue in August 1997 and the Joint Program of Action agreed at the second meeting in August 1998 are both on the public record. Officials gave background briefings to the media at the conclusion of the two sets of talks. I also issued media statements after both meetings and spoke to the press on 10 August 1998. About forty non-government organisations with a particular interest in human rights were given more extensive briefings by senior officers of my Department following the two meetings.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Is an unemployed parent with children from a former relationship, who is not in receipt of child support but is in a relationship with a working partner, entitled to any assistance from Centrelink.
(2) If a person in this situation has entitlements: (a) what assistance is available; and (b) are there any special process conditions applicable.
(3) If there are no entitlements, why not.
(4) Are the unemployed person and the children considered dependants for the purposes of Centrelink assistance.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. An unemployed parent who is the primary carer of a child under 16, would be eligible for Parenting Payment, Family Allowance and possibly Family Tax Payment, subject to income and assets tests and other eligibility requirements.

(2) (a) The maximum rate of Parenting Payment is currently $293.80 per fortnight (pf). The level of payment is affected by the private income of the person (if any), the income of the working partner, and the combined assets of the couple. A Basic Rate of Parenting Payment of $66 pf is payable regardless of the working partner's income and assets, but this payment is affected by personal income.

The maximum rate of Family Allowance is currently $99.00 pf for each child aged under 13 and $128.80 pf for each child aged 13-15. The level of payment is affected by the combined income and assets of the couple and any child support received. Family Allowance is not payable if the couple's yearly income is over $66,725 (two children) or combined assets are over $608,500. Rent Assistance, an add-on to Family Allowance, may also be payable to the person if the family is renting privately.
Family Tax Payment may be paid to low income families who receive more than the minimum rate of Family Allowance. Higher income families may receive equivalent assistance through the tax system.

The current rate of Family Tax Payment is $7.70 pf per child, plus an additional $19.24 pf if there is a child under 5 years and one of the couple has private income less than $176.43 pf. (b) Apart from the income and assets tests there are other tests on whether assistance is payable. These vary

depending on the type of payment. There is a specific requirement that the parent of the children must take action to obtain child support from the non-custodial parent to receive more than the minimum rate of Family Allowance. In some circumstances people are exempt from this requirement.

(4) The concept of adult dependants is generally not a feature of income support under the Social Security Act. An unemployed person with children who is in a relationship with a working partner can apply for Parenting Payment in their own right.
Children are considered dependants for the purposes of payments such as Parenting Payment, Family Payment, Family Tax Payment and Rent Assistance.
